title: coronavirus uk eu ppe ventilators brexit foreign office equipment
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Matt Hancock told the country&nbspon Tuesday that the UK was now in the schemeThe UK is still not taking part in any EU medical equipment purchasing scheme despite the Health Secretary claiming that it had now signed up, Brussels has said.At a Downing Street press briefing on Tuesday Matt Hancock said there was no political decision not to join the procurement scheme and we joined so we are now members of that scheme.However EU officials confirmed on Wednesday that the UK was not involved, despite the deadline for four rounds of purchasing being extended to 12 April to allow for more orders - well after the UK claimed it had missed the deadline to participate.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThey are not participating in any of the existing schemes but they have indicated that they would be open to participating in any future schemes, an EU official told The Independent.The UK is a member of the EU's longstanding joint procurement agreement, the legal basis on which such orders have been conducted - but it has been so since 2014 when the agreement was created and Britain was a member state, a status it inherited in the Brexit transition period.Top official withdraws claim over UK failure to join EU medical schemeA European Commission spokesperson told reporters at a daily press briefing that the UK had ample opportunity to take part in the scheme given its officials were present at four meetings in Brussels where it was discussed. A timeline reconstructed by The Independent at the bottom if the article illustrates the way events played out.Over a period of weeks ministers, civil servants, and spokespeople for the government have oscillated between claiming they did not want to take part in the scheme and claiming that they did not do so because of a miscommunication.The UK was also still able to place orders under the scheme well after Downing Street claimed to have missed the deadline.The EU has placed four different tenders for medical equipment since the start of the crisis, three for personal protective equipment (PPE) and one for ventilators. No equipment has yet been delivered under the scheme, but the quantities and timelines for delivery are agreed inidually by member states when they place orders.The programme uses the purchasing power of the 500 million person single market to secure priority orders during a time of a global shortage. The UK is allowed to participate by virtue of being in the Brexit transition period.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by emailThe UK's lack of participation comes at a time when NHS workers and care staff are warning of shortages of equipment, with dozens of clinicians on the frontline now dead from coronavirus.Most recently the top civil servant at the Foreign Office Sir Simon McDonald told MPs at a hearing in Westminster on Wednesday that it had been a political decision not to join the scheme, recounting how he had spelled out the options to ministers. But after the Health Secretary Mr Hancock's appearance at a press conference in which he denied such a decision had been taken, Sir SimonAsked whether anyone had leant not he civil servant to retract his story, the prime minister‚Äôs official spokesman said: ‚ÄúNobody. It is important that select committees are given accurate information and that‚Äôs why he corrected what he had said. He took the opportunity to correct the record very quickly and in a very clear way.‚ÄùA European Commission spokesperson said on Wednesday: We announced this already very early - if you look for instance and the minutes of the meetings of the health security committee the European Commission already announced on 31 January that it could help member states with the organisation of such joint procurement schemes.This idea of joint procurement and reporting on the states of the medical supplies of member states was a recurring topic on the agenda of the health security meetings.So the UK was, as all other members of the health security committee meetings, aware of the work that was ongoing and had ample opportunity to express its wish to participate in a joint procurement if it wanted to do so. Why it did not participate - this is obviously something on which we cannot comment.The timeline of the episode shows how the government handled the situation:British officials attended a meeting in Brussels during which the European Commission said it was ready to help organise the bulk-buying medical equipment using the power of the single marketBritish officials attended another EU meeting where the Commission's health department said 20 EU countries were ready to join such a scheme for personal protective equipmentBritish officials attended another meeting where EU officials discussed the addition of ventilators to the procurement schemeA spokesperson for the European Commission confirms in public when asked by journalists whether the UK is able to take part in the procurement schemeBoris Johnson is urged by British politicians to join the scheme. In Brussels, the UK takes part in another meeting on joint procurementUrsula von der Leyen announces publicly that the Commission's joint procurement initiative had generated concrete offers of considerable scale at short notice to supply surgical masks, overalls, googles, and face shieldsAsked in the morning why the UK isn't taking part in the scheme, a Downing Street spokesperson says: We are no longer members of the EU'. Boris Johnson is accused off being ideological for not taking partLater in the evening the Prime minister's spokesperson tells Westminster journalists that in fact, a communication error meant the UK had missed the invitation to participate in the schemeAsked why the government did not join the scheme, Cabinet minister Michael Gove tells the Andrew Marr Show there is nothing that we can't do as an independent nation that being part of that scheme would have allowed us to do adding that there was communication confusionHealth Secretary Matt Hancock tells a Downing Street briefing the UK is working hard opening new supply lines for protective equipment around the world to fill a shortageThe extended deadline for putting orders in the latest round of the EU's equipment procurement scheme. The UK has placed no ordersCabinet minister Therese Coffey seems to suggest not going the scheme was a deliberate decision, telling LBC radio: The government has made an assessment that by joining the schemes, it wasn't going to make any particular difference.The Foreign Office's top civil servant Sir Simon McDonald tells MPs he briefed ministers about the options and that they made a political decision not to join the schemeLater in the afternoon, Matt Hancock tells a daily press briefing as far as I'm aware there was no political decision not to participate in that scheme ... we are now members of that scheme.Following the briefing by the Health Secretary, Sir Simon writes to MPs to retract what he told them.Contrary to what Matt Hancock said the day before, EU officials tell The Independent: They are not participating in any of the existing schemes but they have indicated that they would be open to participating in any future schemes.In Brussels, a Commission spokesperson refers to the meetings the EU attended and says there was ample opportunity to join.At a briefing in Westminster, a Downing Street spokesperson says nobody leant on Sir Simon to get him to retract his report to MPs.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users‚Äô, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - Like his brother, he also studied abroad in Switzerland.According to Kenji Fujimoto, the Japanese man who claims to have been the personal sushi chef for Kim Jong-il, the late North Korean leader&nbspdecided Kim Jong-chol was too ‚Äúgirlish‚Äù to lead the country. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.US&nbspsay they fear long-range ballistic technology used to put satellites into orbit could also be used to launch nuclear warheadsIran claimed on Wednesday that it had successfully launched its first-ever military satellite into orbit in a move that experts described as a significant but not game-changing achievement.&nbspIran‚Äôs Revolutionary Guard claimed it had launched the Nur satellite, which experts suggest could serve as a surveillance tool, into orbit 425 kilometres above the earth‚Äôs surface early this morning by firing the two-stage Qassed rocket into space.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesVideo broadcast on Iran‚Äôs state television showed a single white rocket slowly lifting off from a barren location described as somewhere in the country‚Äôs vast Central Desert. ‚ÄúGlory be to God who made this available to us, otherwise we could not have done it,‚Äù said a Koranic inscription on the side of the rocket.&nbspNone of the claims about the satellite launch have yet been independently verified or refuted. The satellite‚Äôs functions remain unclear. Experts say its relatively low orbit suggests it will serve as a surveillance beacon. But any imagery it captures will likely be inferior to those provided by numerous private-sector firms.&nbspIran to reopen shopping malls and bazaars despite coronavirus fearsUS Navy accuses Iran of harassing its ships in the GulfIranian general touts fake bomb-detecting devices to fight coronavirusIran to begin reopening for business despite warnings ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a low earth-orbit satellite,‚Äù said Markus Schiller, a military and space analyst at ST Analytics, a Munich firm. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not in a position to get better imagery than commercial satellites.‚ÄùThe Vienna-based United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs, which tracks objects orbiting the earth, has yet to record the launch.&nbspIn the past, Iran has admitted unsuccessful attempts to fire satellites into orbit. But Iranian hardliners and the Revolutionary Guard have also repeatedly fabricated accomplishments, including by doctoring photos. The Revolutionary Guard this month presented an apparent toy it claimed could detect infections of the novel coronavirus ‚Äúwithin five seconds.‚Äù&nbspIran and the United States are locked in an escalating confrontation, with the administration of President Donald Trump pursuing a policy of ‚Äúmaximum pressure‚Äù against Tehran over its nuclear programme, support for armed allies throughout the Middle East and refinement of its missile technology.Iran‚Äôs communications minister on Twitter emphasised the ‚Äúpeaceful‚Äù and defensive nature of Iran‚Äôs space programme.&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The&nbspmonth of spiritual contemplation will be very different for the majority&nbspof the&nbspworld‚Äôs 1.8 billion MuslimsOn the eve of Ramadan, 1.8 billion Muslims around the world are preparing for the month-long spiritual contemplation unlike ever before.Coronavirus has forced the hands of governments, with traditions that have stood for centuries&nbspunable to be observed due to lockdown&nbspmeasures&nbspaimed at containing&nbspthe spread of the pathogen. Emphasising devotion while fasting and developing an affinity with fellow Muslims, this time would usually see gatherings at mosques, homes and out on&nbspthe streets.But widespread restrictions have been implemented around the world, including a ban in Turkey on tents designed to offer&nbspfree fast-breaking iftar dinners and pre-dawn suhoor meals. Citizens there are also forbidden&nbspfrom tipping drummers walking through the streets to wake people for their last meal before dawn, with the country responding after nearly&nbsp100,000 cases and 2,259 fatalities as of Wednesday afternoon, according to Johns Hopkins University.&nbspCharity tables have also been barred in Egypt, though there have been just&nbsp3,490 cases with&nbspthe death total currently at 264.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesSaudi Arabia has suspended visas for Muslims seeking to take pilgrimages to Mecca and Medina, while Iranian President Hassan Rouhani&nbspwas apologetic&nbspafter&nbspannouncing a ban on the country‚Äôs&nbspusual ceremonies and forbidding the public from&nbspattending holy shrines and mosques for two more weeks at least. Pakistan has walked back restrictions on&nbspgroups of five or less able to&nbspattend prayers at mosques though after&nbspclashes between&nbspworshipers and police.A sombre mood is likely to overshadow much of the month, though the nature of Islam could help Muslims cope better in these&nbsptesting circumstances.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be different and difficult in certain circumstances, but Islam is a very flexible religion, it covers for all circumstances, so the usual worship we would do in mosques, we can do them at home, there‚Äôs no harm in that given the situation,‚Äù&nbspFarhad Ahmad, an Imam&nbspat Fazl Mosque in London, tells The Independent.‚ÄúDuring Ramadan we increase our worship, doing more goodness towards others, paying more to charity. So in a way, given everybody is now at home already, you‚Äôre self-isolating or in quarantine, that is sort of a natural phenomena that usually happens in Ramadan anyway, as people become more devout and less social anyway.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a bit different to what some people think about Ramadan. Being forced into it is not the ideal situation, Ramadan doesn‚Äôt say don‚Äôt go to work or see your friends, but at the same time, there‚Äôs an emphasis to reflect on life, spend more time worshipping God, so this opportunity has made us more aware that we can do this more comfortably.‚ÄùTracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastIndeed the practice of itikaf ‚Äì solitary confinement during&nbspthe final days of Ramadan in a mosque ‚Äì means that many Muslims may be accustomed to their current circumstances, even if they are now at home rather than a place of worships. While many&nbspmosques are now putting on&nbsponline&nbspexercise classes and lectures to the burden on people&nbspduring this time.‚ÄúSome people are going through a difficult time with anxiety, depression or mental health issues,‚Äù Mr Ahmad adds. ‚ÄúBut if you‚Äôre unwell or ill, Islam says you‚Äôre not supposed to fast. There are a lot of challenges, but because Islam is flexible, it allows you to manage in any circumstance.‚ÄùNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: figures show lockdown is starting work
story: THE future of this country depends on decisions made by ministers in the weeks and months ahead.If they relax restrictions too soon, thousands more Brits will lose loved ones before their time.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Butlockdown goes on for too long, the creaking economy will finally croak ‚Äî leaving millions destitute.Which is why now is the wrong moment for aggressive finger-pointing.Yes, Britain‚Äôs initial reaction to the outbreak was far from perfect. Public Health England was embarrassingly underprepared, and it‚Äôs quite possible that ministers or their scientic advisers were too blase.But we are where we are. And brave, wise, le-saving decisions are made by confident politicians at the very top of their game ‚Äî not terried men and women looking over their shoulders and worrying how they‚Äôll be judged at a massively expensive public inquiry.The Government‚Äôs lockdown strategy is backed by an overwhelming majority of the public. And the figures show that it‚Äôs starting to work. Let‚Äôs cut the backseat driving and let Boris and his team get on with it.THE PPE crisis unfolding in hospitals and care homes shames this nation.Britain has the raw materials to kit out staff. Sothe Government and private companies worked effectively together, we have no doubt that our NHS heroes could get the protection they need.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise ¬£MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating ¬£, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThere has been little explanation of why deals between firms and the Government haven‚Äôt been made quickly and effectively.It leaves Britain at the mercy of foreign countries. And the consequences are deadly.When a bunch of box packers at an airport in Turkey make a mistake, our frontline staff are left high and dry.We‚Äôve never been fans of pointless bureaucracy. And when our doctors, nurses and carers are at risk, something has to give. Fast.WE couldn‚Äôt be more proud of the great British public.For four weeks, we‚Äôve been cooped up indoors while the sunshine blazes through the window. But ‚Äî with the exception of a few covidiots ‚Äî we‚Äôve resisted temptation and stuck to the rules.And our tremendous efforts weren‚Äôt in vain. According to one top scientist, Britain is over the first peak.That doesn‚Äôt mean we‚Äôre out of the woods yet. story: WE are all pulling together following the rules, helping our neighbours, applauding the NHS ‚Äì a genuinely United Kingdom.But the blame game is already in full swing.Labour‚Äôs vow to avoid playing party politics with a global emergency has bitten the dust, with Boris Johnson effectively accused of leaving voters to die.But it‚Äôs the Opposition‚Äôs job to oppose and politicians are paid to take the flak.Broadcasters and newspapers, including our Sunday Times stablemate, are piling in with suggestions Boris has been fiddling while Rome burned.They claim the PM was skiving on five-day weeks while spending weekends at Chevening, a ‚Äúgrace-and- favour country retreat‚Äù in Kent, instead of tackling the incoming apocalypse.As the earliest reports of the disease were reaching the West, the idle blighter was ‚Äúsunning himself‚Äù on the luxury island of Mustique with pregnant fianc√©e Carrie Symonds.This, remember, was after the longest war of political attrition ever seen in a hostile House of Commons and an exhausting General Election where Boris scored a landslide victory.Nobody in Europe or America was raising the Covid- alarm at this time.As French President Emanuel Macron admitted last week, the entire Western world was caught on the hop. His government has ‚Äúmade mistakes‚Äù ‚Äî and so has ours.But presidents and prime ministers have a lot on their plates. When it comes to health alarms, they rely on experts.It would take a very brave prime minister indeed to ignore the people appointed to safeguard the nation‚Äôs health when lives are at risk.And the advice from those experts ‚Äî the sprawling Public Health England in particular ‚Äî was that Britain faced no more than a larger-than-usual dose of winter flu.PHE was against German-style mass testing and, when caught flat-footed, rejected help from commercial laboratories in providing those tests.PHE failed to build stocks of personal protective equipment ‚Äî including masks, gowns and gloves ‚Äî despite a  test run showing these were a priority.PHE dragged its feet over sourcing ventilators for intensive-care patients and extra hospital beds.Frequently when running short of crucial gear, PHE resisted offers of outside help, leaving the NHS scrambling to catch up.And when it came to opening London‚Äôs ,-bed Nightingale emergency hospital, it was the Army that did the job in nine days.It was also PHE who insisted the British public would be protected by ‚Äúherd immunity‚Äù.The sooner  per cent of the population had contracted the virus and become immune, the better, it said.Boris faithfully followed their lead until another expert, Prof Neil Ferguson, issued a nightmare prediction of , dead unless Britain was locked up overnight.It was Ferguson who in the Blair years forecast mass burials on the scale of the Great Plague during the ‚ÄúMad Cow‚Äù scare and the foot-and-mouth outbreak.Neither Armageddon scenario came remotely close.Once this is over and the inevitable inquiry is held, Boris and his government will inevitably be in the dock.So will PHE, a fiercely territorial quango with a giant ¬£.billion budget.Much of this goes on pay and perks for well-cushioned executives, with  staff on six-figure salaries ‚Äî a nanny-state rich list.Its website boasts its job is to ‚Äúprotect and improve the nation‚Äôs health and wellbeing‚Äù.And yet this box-ticking bureaucracy ‚Äî obsessed with sugary drinks and ersity ‚Äî has failed at the first hurdle.It shares with the higher reaches of the NHS a suspicion of fleet-footed commercial rivals and deep-seated hostility to the ‚Äúprofit motive‚Äù.Criticism, still muted, is widespread within the medical community, including frontline doctors and consultants.Every Thursday at pm, a grateful nation stands and applauds NHS staff working around the clock to save lives at the risk of their own.The same cannot be said for the inflexible, politically correct quango that binds the hands of medical staff in the name of an outdated socialist credo on health provision: State good, private bad.Much will need to change after Covid-. And that change must start with Public Health England.MINISTERS are looking at a traffic-light system to lt lockdown. Red for Stop, green for Go, with amber in between.Overzealous cops and councils are being reined in. ¬≠Common sense is taking over. Families can now attend funerals.We might be able to say goodbye to dying ¬≠relatives. Parks will reopen to the ¬≠public. Benches have been deemed safe to sit on.So how about allowing non-contact sporting activities that boost both physical and mental health Swimming pools are surely safe. title: coronavirus pandemic freedom britain orwell
story: IMAGINE a Britain where everyone dutully carries an identity card and the Government tracks the movements of all its terried citizens.It is a bleak world of curfews and crackdowns, of mass surveillance and monitoring systems - with facial recognition cameras looming over every street corner.¬†In public spaces, loudspeakers blare out official safety messages. On each phone there is an app that reports back to the authorities on the users‚Äô health and online activities.Nor is there any escape in the home. The very concept of privacy barely exists when the state can use sophisticated technology to keep watch on our behaviour.This vision sounds like a nightmare, but it could become all too real thanks to the coronavirus.In its fallout, Covid- may end up causing as much damage to our essential freedoms as to our health - with the new menace of Big Brother on its way.Already the current emergency has led to the first comprehensive lockdown in British history.Evenit has been necessary to slow the spread of the virus, it is nevertheless a draconian measure that would have been unthinkable only a few weeks ago.Effectively the entire public has been placed under house arrest.Normal le has been brought juddering to a halt, while the police have been given unprecedented powers to enforce the quarantine.Even sitting for too long on a park bench or taking a leisurely drive have become offences against the state.With heroic stoicism, the vast majority of people have accepted this policy, seeing it as the only realistic means to protect the NHS and lessen the transmission of coronavirus.They hope that once the worst of the crisis has passed, there will be ato the Britain that they love, where inidual rights are respected and the power of the state is limited.Above all, this is my deepest wish too - though the chances look slim.One of the reasons why I, as an Irishman, admire this country so much is because of the British tradition of liberty, reflected in Magna Carta, parliamentary democracy and the defeat of Nazi tyranny.Unfortunately, even when the current lockdown is lted, it is possible that heavy-handed control by the state will remain.Quarantine may be temporary, but authoritarianism could be permanent.This is because officialdom, shaken by the unexpected scale of the coronavirus crisis, will be determined to prevent its resurgence by any means necessary.That will involve far more than just the maintenance of social distancing and the wearing of face masks.An arsenal of other measures could be deployed in the fight.One will be the reintroduction of curfews at the first sign of any new flare up in cases.If there is such a setback, the mood of the authorities will be even more intolerant towards any breaches. Fines will be heavier, jail terms longer.The skies will be filled with the sound of helicopters and the sight of drones as police ‚Äî or even the Army ‚Äî embark on ruthless enforcement.Another change is likely to be the advent of biometric identity cards, backed up by a comprehensive database of the entire population.Such a system has long been the dream of bureaucrats in Whitehall, and the aftermath of the crisis provides the perfect excuse for its imposition.Its appeal is all the greater because the latest type of cards operate with biotechnology that scans eyes and fingerprints.Only last year, the European Union passed a regulation requiring all national identity card systems on the continent to comply with new biometric standards.The British state will not stop there in its new crusade.In the name of health protection, mobile phone companies could be required to share data on their clients.According to the New Statesman, British Telecom, which owns the EE network, is already ‚Äúin talks with the Government about handing over phone location and usage data‚Äù for the purpose of monitoring adherence to the lockdown.Similarly, tracking apps on devices could also be made obligatory so that the Government will be able to trace the contacts of anyone infected and ensure compliance with quarantine rules.Just as some criminals on release have to wear electronic tags, anyone who has tested positive for the virus may be ordered to wear a medical wristband even when self-isolation is over.Alternatively, those who test negative could be given immunity certicates.These initiatives will be accompanied by a political drive to reinforce support for the state, as happens in wartime.In a distinctly un-British way, people will be encouraged to snitch on those who fail to abide by the rules.Challenges to ruling orthodoxy will be seen as a form of subversion.If that sounds far-fetched, consider how laws to tackle discrimination or terrorism are now used to uphold fashionable ideology, as highlighted in the outrageous recent case where Lincolnshire businessman Harry Miller was questioned by police for allegedly sending a ‚Äútransphobic‚Äù tweet.In the new Britain scarred by corona, the whole relationship between the state and the public will be inverted.The Government is meant to be accountable to the people.But, burdened with ID cards, curfews and tracking apps, the people will be accountable to the Government.There is an echo here of the George Orwell‚Äôs novel , which painted a terrying picture of Britain under totalitarian rule.In Orwell‚Äôs society gripped by permanent crisis, the citizenry were monitored day and night by the state.The propaganda and all-seeing eye of Big Brother could never be avoided, ‚Äúalways watching and the voice enveloping you, asleep or awake, indoors or outdoors, in the bath or in bed.In the present global crisis, many look to the experience of Asia, which has had far lower Covid death rates than the West.But that is a dangerous stance. First it ignores the fundamental point that China is responsible for the spread of this disease through its cover-up, persecution and lies.The country should be in the dock, not garnered with praise.Second it glosses over the oppressive nature of many of these Asian regimes, particularly that run by the tyrannical Chinese communist party.China has eagerly embraced new technology, like tracking devices, facial recognition cameras, eye-scanning security barriers and online data gathering, precisely because they drastically enhance the power of the state machine.Indeed, the country likes to boast that it is building the ‚Äúworld‚Äôs largest camera surveillance network‚Äù.As an example, in Guangzhou province, the commercial hub of southern China, tablets have been recently installed on buses to promote safety.Passengers are expected to lean their foreheads close to the tablet so that their photos and temperatures can be taken.China is also establishing a sinister ‚Äúsocial credit system‚Äù, where behaviour is monitored to assess a citizen‚Äôs trustworthiness.Those given high ratings by the state can receive rewards like employment offers, shorter waiting times in hospitals and discounts at hotels.It is a recipe for bureaucratic despotism and political infantilisation.Other Asian nations, while nothing like as cruel as China, are also using technology as a tool to corral their public.Hong Kong has introduced mandatory wristbands for those in quarantine so they can be tracked.Taiwan has a monitoring system known as ‚Äúthe electronic fence‚Äù where those who are meant to be in isolation will be visited by the authoritiesthey turn off their mobiles.In South Korea, the government gathers huge amounts of data from phone records, CCTV images, and credit cards to help track citizens during the Covid crisis, while in Singapore, phone users are encouraged to download the ‚ÄúTraceTogether‚Äù app.This keeps a record of all the other numbers that have been in close proximity to the smartphone, making it easier to trace anyone who might have been near the owner in the event of a positive Covid-test.Not all of these developments are bad, provided they are genuinely used as weapons against disease rather than vehicles for the expansion of state power.But we have seen since   how the excuse of security can be used as a cover for bullying by the authorities, with the result that international air travel is often a miserable experience.A No spokesman said: ‚ÄúThe NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.‚ÄùSAS hero Andy McNab added: ‚ÄúThe award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.‚ÄùWe are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.We should not allow the same to happen on a national scale in the wake of the pandemic.As the great author C.S.Lewis wrote: ‚ÄúOf all tyrannies, a tyranny exercised for the good of its victims may be the most oppressive.It would be better to live under robber barons than omnipotent moral busybodies.‚ÄùTo receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.¬†Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: coronavirus brutal caning unmarried couple indonesia
story: BRUTAL canings are still taking place for unmarried couples who breach Islamic law despite coronavirus lockdown measures.¬†Pictures show men and women receiving the vicious punishment from the religious police in the ultra-conservative province of Aceh in Indonesia.Six people were flogged for violating the extreme interpretation of Islamic law in the vicious ceremony on Tuesday, April .One unmarried couple were punished for being caught together in a hotel room.Four other people were also given  lashes for drinking alcohol in violation of the law, known as Qanun.Huge crowds normally gather for the religious punishment - but only a handful of spectators appeared to have attended due to the coronavirus pandemic.The few onlookers could be seen wearing face masks and some appeared to be obeying social distance guidelines.Indonesia has , confirmed cases of Covid- and  deaths as the virus continues to spread worldwide.One of the victims could also be seen wearing a face mask as he was treated by medics after his caning.And of course the punishments enforcer was wearing the traditional hood and gloves as he wielded the rattan cane.Flogging is used as a punishment for a range of religious offences in the region at the tip of the island of Sumatra.A local official said: To comply with current conditions, were trying to cut unnecessary procedures like the usual opening speech.We just carried out the flogging directly to make it simpler.Whipping will still go on, but were limiting the number of people involved.Aceh is the only region in Indonesia that imposes Islamic law, with  per cent of its five million residents being Muslim.It adopted sharia law after being granted a degree of autonomy from the national government in .The most vicious punishment is  lashes, which is administered for the most severe crimes along with prison time.One of the victims caned for drinking alcohol said he was actually relieved to take the corporal punishment rather than serve more jail time.He said: I got bored in prison and now Im finally a free man.Human rights groups have condemned the brutal punishments as inhumane, but they have wide support in Aceh.Indonesias president Joko Widodo has expressed support for doing away with the practice to improve the provinces image.Speaking in , vice governor Nova Iriansyah suggested the whippings may be moved into a private setting to avoid press attention.Amnesty International has condemned the practice, saying last year the canings are violations of international human rights law.The group said: Punishable offences include consensual intimacy or sexual activity for unmarried couples, consensual sex outside marriage, same-sex sexual relations, the consumption and sale of alcohol, and gambling.Under international human rights law all forms of corporal punishment are prohibited ‚Äì they violate the absolute prohibition of torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading punishment and often torture.Meanwhile, the coronavirus infection total neared .million worldwide - with UK announcing plans to roll out testing of an experimental vaccine.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: clearest puma britain cumbria

title: harry meghan boycotting publicity
story: Begging the question: Will any of us actually notice For, despite largely positive coverage by the pro-monarchy outlets in question, this self-aggrandising couple have barely engaged with them on any level beyond sending threatening legal letters.So they could have just continued as normal and skipped the part where, yet again, they create a drama when none exists while simultaneously claiming that they want to live a quiet le.But all that aside, it was the timing of their breathtakingly imperious statement that really stank.The world is in lockdown, trying to combat a killer virus, people are dying in their thousands, others are losing their businesses or jobs and young people are struggling to cope with being cooped up away from their friends.So what do the self-appointed King and Queen of mental health issues do  Once again they try to pull focus and make it all about them.On top of that, the decision to release it on the eve of the Queen‚Äôs official th birthday meant that the next day‚Äôs headlines were dominated by the Sussexes‚Äô childish, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not talking to you any more‚Äù declaration.Bless them, they even sent it tonewspaper, which has remained on their approved list of media outlets despite wanting to scrap the monarchy upon which their ever-dwindling kudos is based.It resists writing much about the Sussexes because it regards them as largely irrelevant, not because it‚Äôs showing deference to their, er, greatness, by toeing whatever PR line they‚Äôre churning out on any given week.Meanwhile, the pro-royal newspapers and, more importantly, their collective millions of readers, have been placed on the naughty step.But then, as the Queen‚Äôs former, long-running adviser Dickie Arbiter ‚Äî who has known Harry since he was four ‚Äî put it: ‚ÄúPrince Harry is not the brightest bunny on the planet.‚ÄùIt was all going so well, wasn‚Äôt it For a multitude of reasons ‚Äî among them his launch of the inspiring Invictus games ‚Äî Harry was always our favourite royal by a country mile.But despite a glorious and much-celebrated wedding day and glowing coverage of his first official tour with his new we, his ‚Äúcheeky chappie‚Äù demeanour changed and he seemingly became more brooding and bitter, particularly towards the newspapers his more media-savvy mother had actively courted.Today, ‚Äúthe media‚Äù is an all-encompassing term that includes not just newspapers and magazines, but rolling news channels, websites and the ubiquitous ‚Äúsocial media‚Äù that, one suspects, Harry just lumps together as one single irritant.A journalist, who spent time with him for an article, revealed that he reads everything written about him and Meghan, which ‚Äî as anyone in the public eye will tell you ‚Äî is the route to madness.Far better to view gossipy, rather than wholly factual, stories asthey were one of those Amaretti biscuit wrappers you set fire to in restaurants ‚Äî something that burns brightly for mere moments before vaporising into the ether.If Harry applied that philosophy, he‚Äôd find his mental health would improve markedly.But instead he has turned his legal guns on four tabloid newspapers for ‚Äúdistorted,  or invasive beyond reason‚Äù coverage with-out providing a single example.Newspapers do get things wrong occasionally, but there are checks and balances in place for corrections and, of course, laws too.The internet, by comparison, is the Wild West.But hey ho. As I say, this baffling statement will make zero dference to their already fractured relationship with the UK.In an ideal world, every media outlet worldwide would form a pact that they will never again write about or use a photograph of the Sussexes.The effect would be swt and damning.For without the oxygen of publicity, what are they Married to a home-body, I have always rather envied those whose other halves travel frequently for their job.It gives you the house to yourself sporadicallyand makes you appreciate them when they .But in lockdown we are faring well because we are already used to being together most of the time.A friend whose husband usually travels for work called me the other day to say that his sudden, constant presence in the home was causing friction.And yesterday, Boyzone star Shane Lynch announced the sad news that lockdown has put his -year marriage to Sheena White under intolerable strain.He says: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not even in my family home right now because me and her were at each other‚Äôs throats.‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt a good time or a good space.‚ÄúI‚Äôm usually on the road and for the first time I‚Äôve spent three months in my house . . . it can be a struggle.‚ÄùIndeed it can. Let‚Äôs hope they sort it out for the sake of their two children.Now the dust has settled around Professor Neil Ferguson‚Äôs original estimate of , Covid deaths, it‚Äôs perhaps time to stand back and take a logical overview of the situation.While the death toll is still worrying, the mantra that we are critically harming the economy to protect the NHS from being overwhelmed is undermined by the news that many of the private hospitals repurposed for Covid patients are lying virtually empty and the ,-bed facility set up in London‚Äôs ExCel centre is only treating  people.It‚Äôs adding credence to the burgeoning mindset that, perhaps, those who are considered vulnerable should remain in lockdown while the rest of the country makes a gradualto school or work while maintaining strict social distancing measures.On GMB yesterday, a gruff, Swedish professor, whose name escaped me, was asked to explain the thinking behind his country‚Äôs policy to keep everything open.He replied: ‚ÄúPeople are not stupid.‚ÄùIn other words, the Swedes are taking personal responsibility for how they behave and, as of earlier this week, the death rate was starting to decline.It remains to be seen whether Sweden‚Äôs outlier stance proves to be the correct one, but one thing is for certain: Its economy may be weakened at the end of it, but it won‚Äôt be on the critical list like ours.Model and businessman David Gandy talked about the importance of fostering at the weekend, under the headline, ‚ÄúOMG. He‚Äôs so cute!‚ÄùIndeed he is, was my immediate thought. My second was that I would happily foster him anytime.However, it turns out the headline and suggestion of benevolence was aimed at Dora, his rescue pup from Battersea Dogs Home, for which David is an ambassador.He says: ‚ÄúWhat I love about the evenings now is the calmness of a tired, sleeping dog at your side. I watch Dora dreaming.‚ÄùLucky Dora.One wondersshe knows that, when it comes to good fortune, she has won the canine equivalent of the Lottery.Last year, I read to kids in a primary school and, with rare exception, every time I asked what they wanted to be when they grew up, they replied: ‚ÄúA YouTuber.‚ÄùYet last week, while queuing behind a mother and her daughter outside the supermarket, the young girldeclared her desire to become a nurse when she left school.Now that is something positive to come out of the Covid- crisis.Jigsaws are getting me through the long days of lockdown.Despite The Bloke‚Äôs lame attempts to hide the last pieceI completed my fth at the weekend and, as an exercise in mindfulness, it‚Äôs right up there with any yoga retreat.So imagine my joy when Kodak announced last week that it has produced the world‚Äôs largest jigsaw with, gulp, , pieces.It is  separate images of world landmarks and, when finished, covers  square metres ‚Äì about the size of a standard living room. title: coronavirus matt hancock testing fiasco
story: WE sympathise with Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary unenviably copping the flak for every Covid setback. But he has to stop spinning and be honest.Let us say first, though, that he is right to rejoice that the NHS and its increased capacity has coped so far with this catastrophe. And that the nation HAS heeded the call to protect it and save lives.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise ¬£MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating ¬£, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealIn fact we have gone far further, raising millions for NHS staff via hero Captain Tom Moore and The Sun‚Äôs Who Cares Wins appeal ‚Äî while big-hearted volunteers are working flat-out to sew together much-needed PPE and scrubs.And it is potentially fantastic news that human vaccine trials start in Oxford on Thursday, an amazing feat given that these processes normally take years.Those are all positives.But Mr Hancock should stop pretending his testing strategy is anything but a fiasco.Tests are going DOWN.He promised , a day by next Thursday.Why  It merely set him up for humiliation.Andwe can now carry out , a day, why are only , done Why are NHS staff forced to travel huge distances to a testing centre, only to be turned away Why aren‚Äôt far, far more being testedthe capacity exists On PPE, why announce huge new stocks before they are in hand Or sit for weeks on solid offers from UK suppliers On masks, why claim to be still evaluating the ‚Äúscience‚Äù on their effectiveness, when they are already vital in hospitals and care homes and routinely worn abroad The Government really just wants to prevent a public stampede when NHS staff need them more.This crisis is grim enough without people feeling misled by those they are trusting to see us through it.THE petrol price rip-off is laid bare as never before.For the first time, oil costs less than nothing. Yes, you read that right.Is fuel plummeting on our forecourts  Of course not.Retailers say they cannot afford that, because they‚Äôre still flogging petrol and diesel bought at higher ¬≠prices. title: gastro coronavirus symptoms
story: A persistent dry cough and fever are the two main symptoms we know to look for, but scientists have said Covid- can attack our digestive systems as well, a version known as gastro coronavirus.Dr Fern Riddell, historian and author, detailed on Twitter her digestive symptoms as shes battled coronavirus.On April  she tweeted: Hello, I‚Äôve not been here because I am on day  of #Covid , and for the last  I‚Äôve been the sickest I‚Äôve ever been in my le.I feel really lucky not to have had any respiratory symptoms, mine have been purely gastric, but even with mild to moderate symptoms, it‚Äôs horrible.She said she felt like she had a summer cold and slight fever and lost her sense of¬† smell - another symptom coronavirus sufferers have also reported having.Dr Riddell said things took a turn for the worse by day .She wrote: Full body shakes and aches, serious dehydration , overwhelming nausea, awful diarrhoea, extreme fatigue.You feel so, so ill. And it‚Äôs terrying. I don‚Äôt remember much of the next  days.A recent study, published in the American Journal of Gastroenterology, suggests people might experience digestive issues, such as diarrhoea, when they are infected with coronavirus.Researchers analysed data from  patients with Covid- in China‚Äôs Hubei province and they discovered that . per cent of these patients arrived at the hospital with digestive symptoms such as diarrhoea, vomiting or abdominal pain.Following this, the researchers stated that, for some people, digestive symptoms may present itself first before the respiratory symptoms of Covid-.The study noted: These data emphasize that patients with new-onset digestive symptoms after a possible Covid- contact should be suspected for the illness, even in the absence of cough, shortness of breath, sore throat, or fever.It also explained that patients with digestive symptoms suffered longer than those with respiratory symptoms - citing the average hospital stay as . days.In the study, the people included in the study also had a more severe case of illness.Brennan M.R. Spiegel, co-editor-in-chief of the American Journal of Gastroenterology, said: In this study, Covid- patients with digestive symptoms have a worse clinical outcome and higher risk of mortality compared to those without digestive symptoms, emphasising the importance of including symptoms like diarrhoea to suspect Covid- early in the disease course before respiratory symptoms develop.Despite this revelation, people should still be vigilant in looking out for the primary symptoms of coronavirus including a dry cough and high temperature, as well as shortness of breath - as Covid- primarily attacks the lungs and respiratory system.Some patients may also have aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose or a sore throat - but these are usually mild and begin gradually.Developing these symptoms does not necessarily mean you have the illness and they are similar to other illnesses, such as the common cold or flu.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Experts have passed on research showing that coverings could help to stop asymptomatic people - those who are infected but not showing symptoms - from passing on the disease.The guidance is set to say that those who cant stay more than m apart at work and on buses and trains should wear a cloth face mask, such as a homemade mask, scarf or other non-surgical covering to help slow the spread of the virus.Experts from SAGEmet yesterday to consider key evidence.Ministers are expected to study the findings over the next few days before making the decision public and changing official guidance.Its believed that the experts think face coverings wont help stop Brits from catching the virus themselves, but could help in stopping them spread it to others.A Whitehall source told The Sun: No decision is going to be made which would take medical masks away from the NHS.Everybody is very clear on that.However, there are fears that changing advice on masks may mean sick Brits venture outside instead of staying isolated in their homes.The source said: Experts are clear that this is not substitution for isolation.If people have any symptoms, they must stay at home.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said of changes to mask guidance this lunchtime: We will follow the advice and listen to what SAGE says on masks and implement that.But he said that the Government would not be handing them out at scale.No refused to comment on what SAGE‚Äôs advice to ministers is.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise ¬£MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating ¬£, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThey also believe that by branding them as face coverings - prevent the spread of coronavirus.Here we take a look at some of the dferent types of face mask and how well they work...N respiratorsN masks are disposable face masks that are proven to filter the air to an industrial standard.Manufacturers y, but the N is a stamp from the US National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health to show that it is efficient.The N stands for Not resistant to oil, because the mask only protects against particles, not fluids while the  means it filters out  per cent of airborne particles.They generally have an -hour shelf le before becoming clogged due to supply issues for health workers.Surgical masksThese disposable -ply masks are fluid-resistant are the most common type of facial protection youll see health care staff wearing.They are used to prevent infected droplets from doctors, nurses and carers entering the respiratory system of the patient.Although they dont have built-in air filters, they are considered effective enough for most staff outside of intensive care.The nose clip can be bent to fit snugly around the nose however they are a loose fit and the material gapes at the sides so they dont protect against all particles.When they become wet, their effectiveness is also reduced.Also, they are disposable and are only intended to be worn once.DIY dust masks Found in most hardware stores, dust masks can offer some level of protection from particles -worn correctly.If it says FFP then it‚Äôs a basic kind of dust mask and offers the lowest level of filtration for this kind of respirators mask.To meet European standards, they have to be able to filter at least  per cent of particles - with FFP  filtering  per cent.That means that it can‚Äôt filter out tiny particles associated with viruses and bacteria.You can also get a FFP mask, which looks similar but has a small filter in the middle to catch almost all airborne particles.Short of being a full gas mask, it offers the best protection - as long as it fits properly - and is more effective than an N as well as the FFP and FFP.Cycling masksThese are generally worn by cyclists to prevent them from breathing in pollution in heavy traffic.Usually made from neoprene, they fit tightly to the face and are intended to offer a level of protection from airborne particles.Some are also marketed as N, or N grade, which means the amount of filtered airborne particles is either  or  per cent.Homemade masksAs many people cant get their hands on a mask, some have turned to fashioning their own.There have been tips on using vacuum cleaner bags and even sanitary towels to cover your face.While most wont be as effective as anything you can buy in a store, they will offer more protection than not covering your face at all.Research by Public Health England in  looked at the suitability of household materials that could be used as maks to filter bacterial and viral aerosols and found vacuum bags actually worked well.Experts say that you should aim for multiple layers - a double layer of tightly-woven cotton with a thread count of at least  was one of the best barriers, according to researchers in the US.Even a bandana, scarf or T-shirt can be used to cover your nose and mouth while in public.¬†But earlier this week  top doctors called for the public to wear face coverings whenever they leave their home, piling pressure on scientists to story: Kimberly Phelps, , wasnt wearing pants or shoes when she allegedly attempted to kidnap a -year-old girl on Scenic Drive in Vine Grove, Kentucky.The victim reportedly told the Meade County Sherfs Office that the woman, wearing just a T-shirt, emerged form a small patch of woods, grabbed her from behind, covered her mouth and tried to drag her away, according to WAVE.Ive been watching you for awhile, the teen claimed the woman said.The arrest report states Phelps was seen to have scratches on her arm when she leapt from the woods around .pm on April .After Phelps allegedly tried to pull the teen closer several times, the victim was able to get away and run to a friends house, WAVE reported.The teen reportedly told police she was¬†afraid for her le and thought she was going to die.Police found Phelps walking near the location of alleged incident - reportedly wearing black pants but no shoes - and questioned her about what reportedly happened.Phelps then attempted to sell the deputy yard sale items, WDRB reported.However, the deputy reported later realizing that drinking glasses that had belonged to the teen matched glasses at Phelps‚Äô yard sale.Police apprehended Phelps and charged her with attempted kidnapping of a minor.Phelps is being held in Meade County Detention Center.The alleged kidnapping attempt comes after Phelps was accused of being intoxicated and disorderly at a Walgreens in March.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: downing street back ban wet markets coronavirus
story: Both China and Vietnam banned the markets which sell live and dead animals for people to eat - but they have continued to trade as the deadly virus grips the world.China has allowed the wildle trade to continue after the World Health Organisation gave the green light for the markets to reopen, despite their own country-wide ban.But No said today they would be pushing China to do more to put a stop to the practice.A spokesperson said: We want to see them enforce that ban.That includes banning wildle markets, banning the sale of wildle in wet markets and taking strong action against anyone who does.Wet markets can be a high risk environment for transmission of viruses from animals to humans.They have announced a ban, we want to see them enforce it.The global pandemic is believed to have first started at a wet market in Wuhan.Boris Johnsons fianc√© Carrie Symonds announced yesterday she had signed a petition calling for an end to the trade.The petition called on governments around the world to recognise the urgency to prevent future pandemics, warrants the permanent end to the commercial trade and sale in markets of terrestrial wild animalsfor consumption.China has previously brought in bans because of epidemics and then relaxed them.After the SARS outbreak in , which, like COVID-, was traced to a wet market, China put a ban on markets and the wild-animal trade industry.But only months after the WHO declared the SARS virus contained, China lted the ban.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise ¬£MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get title: captain tom sent more than 40000 100th birthday cards
story: The World War II veteran will celebrate his birthday on April , after raising ¬£million for NHS charities.Captain Tom, from Marstone Moretaine, Bedfordshire, has received so many birthday cards that staff at his grandson‚Äôs school are sorting them in their hall.The -year-old captured the nation‚Äôs heart when he walked  laps of his garden to raise money for the NHS as it battles coronavirus.His original target was ¬£,, but Captain Tom‚Äôs JustGiving page has now raised over ¬£million from more than . million donations.Ahead of his centenary next week, the South Midlands Mail Centre in Northampton was flooded with letters sending birthday wishes.Bedford School, attended by Captain Tom‚Äôs grandson, Benjie, stepped in to help open and store the cards.Bill Chandi, who has run the local post office for the last  years, said he has ‚Äúnever seen anything like this.He told the Bedford Independent: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre ecstatic for Tom. Whenever he used to pop into our shop he‚Äôd always say to me that post offices are at the centre of the community.‚ÄúI spoke to him on Saturday and told him that‚Äôs certainly true now.‚ÄùSorting machines at the mail centre have even been reprogrammed to separate Captain Tom‚Äôs cards into a dedicated collection box, with staff expecting thousands more in the coming days.Stephen James, who manages the centre, told the BBC: ‚ÄúNone of the team have ever known one person receive so much mail.‚ÄùFrom next week, Royal Mail will use a special postmark to celebrate the World War II veteran‚Äôs birthday, which will appear on all stamped mail across the UK.But that‚Äôs not the end of Captain Tom‚Äôs birthday celebrations ‚Äì an RAF team are also planning to fly a Spitfire past his home.A group of aircraft restorers have asked the Department for Transport for approval to fly the World War II plane over the veteran‚Äôs home.Alex Monk, , from the Biggin Hill Heritage Hangar told The : ‚ÄúIt will be a bit of a morale booster for us all really, to see a Spitfire in the sky. story: With  million Americans filing for unemployment, the historic government bailout was supposed to be a leline. independent contractors and self-employed people.If businesses continue to pay their employees for eight weeks, the government is forgiving the loans.The loan proceeds are used to cover payroll costs, and most mortgage interest, rent, and utility costs over the  week period after the loan is made.At  per cent interest, the forgivable loan guarantees that employee and compensation levels are maintained, saving a lot of jobs as over  million Americans have lost their jobs since coronavirus hit the US.The wage compensation is capped at , annual salary per employee.The total PPP is capped at title: terrifying moment birds prey three poodles through apartment window
story: Gabriela Leonardi, who owns the three French poodles, initially posted the video to TikTok before it was widely shared by Spanish media.In the video, the pair of condors can be seen landing on the penthouse balcony railings after spotting the pups.The three dogs bark excitedly as the gigantic birds size them up from outside the window.One of the condors moves down the railings in order to get closer to the pups but the glass window continues to separate the predator from the prey.The condor begins to peck the window in an attempt to get at one of the dogs.Ms Leonardi is convinced the birds are harmless and only want to play with her pets.She said: The¬†condors¬†come here quite a lot at the moment, the video of them playing with the dogs that everyone is talking about is from a month ago, but especially since the lockdown they have certainly been him more frequently.Gabriela said that about two years ago the larger of the birds, a male, been spotted outside her home but that later he had been joined by a female and then the third bird had started turning up as well.She admitted it was much more frequent since the lockdown and has even given the water to drink.The pet owner is also giving them scraps from her barbecue.Condors across the city have been left hungry due to the departure of people from the local streets from the coronavirus lockdown.In the wild, Condors prefer to eat carrion, Andean condors have been noted to sometimes hunt small live animals such as birds, rabbits and rodents.According to local media, the birds of prey are struggling to survive in the city as people stay at home during the pandemic.Across the world, wild animals have been venturing out into the streets which have been left deserted due to the virus.In the UK, deers have taken over the deserted East London streets as they make the most of the coronavirus lockdown.The deer were pictured catching some rays on a grassy area in front of a row of houses as locals obeyed government lockdown rules.In the US, multiple Twitter-users have spotted coyotes roaming the streets of San Francisco during the three-week lockdown.In Benidorm, a colony of seagulls were spotted preying on an elderly shopper who was carrying their shopping.Locals claimed online the aggressive birds have now taken to attacking people on brief trips for groceries in the ghost town resort.Their normal source of food is said to have vanished after bars and restaurants were shut.

story: ARMY boss General Sir Nicholas Carter gave -year-old war veteran Captain Tom Moore a shout out for his efforts to raise money for the NHS.Chief of Defence Staff Sir Nicholas praised Captain Tom who raised ¬£ million for NHS charities by walking  laps of his garden before his th birthday.Sir Nick said: Weve even mobilised -year-old veterans.Captain Tom Moore embodies the sense of serve and duty ingrained in all our armed forces.He said the Army - You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailKeir Starmer doesn‚Äôt seem like the kind of person who has spent much time idly daydreaming about what his first time at Prime Minister‚Äôs Questions would be like. Buthe had, I doubt it would have been like this. He squared up against Boris Johnson‚Äôs stand-in, Dominic Raab, in a mostly empty Commons chamber, while most MPs chimed in on webcams. Andyou thought Starmer‚Äôs PMQ‚Äôs debut would be a nerve-wracker, spare a thought for Lindsay Hoyle - presiding over the first ‚Äòvirtual‚Äô PMQs. On top of his usual job refereeing the clash of leaders, Sir Lindsay was in charge of making sure MPs were all fully dressed. Or at least that their laptop cameras were positioned so as not to reveal their missing trousers. The whole thing had an air of a phone in interview on a Saturday morning kids show in the s, with Sir Lindsay playing a young Sarah Greene or Philip Schofield. ‚ÄúAnd now we‚Äôre going to go to Peter in Wellingborough,‚Äù he almost said. ‚ÄúPeter, are you there  What‚Äôs your question for the First Secretary.‚Äù Starmer, for his part, set the tone early on - staying on top of the detail and reacting to the answers he was given. He opened by quizzing Johnson‚Äôs understudy on the government‚Äôs increasingly optimistic pledge to perform , coronavirus tests every day, noting with admirable restraint that we‚Äôre ‚Äúbehind the curve‚Äù delivering just , a day with just  days to go.  Raab, who looks like what might happenBruce Banner was interrupted halfway through turning into the Incredible Hulk, reared up for a spot of goalpost repositioning. He tried to ‚Äòcorrect‚Äô the new leader, noting testing capacity was now more than , - well on its way to the promised hundred grand. But ever the former lawyer, Starmer ed to his feet, reminding Raab that the pledge wasn‚Äôt about capacity, it was about tests performed. It was the kind of on-the-spot reaction that Ministers hate and which Jeremy Corbyn used to struggle with so much - the former leader instead relying on pre-prepared questions that played well in social media clips.  Speaking of Starmer‚Äôs predecessor, Mr Corbyn took his seat on the back benches in person, steadfastly refusing to ‚Äòphone it in‚Äô with most other MPs despite so many years of practice. Quite why Mr Corbyn keeps insisting on turning up to Parliament in person, like Banquo looking for a sandwich, rather than staying home and stroking El Gato escapes me. Unless of course he‚Äôs cursed with a slow internet connection, which perhaps raises questions about his election pledge to provide free super fast Broadband for every household. Raab, whose broad, muscular neck would make a perfectly good measuring stick for social distancing rules, managed not to screw anything up or get noticeably rattled. The ever-present vein on his forehead pulsed, but didn‚Äôt burst. He even managed to get most of the numbers right - despite not being able to put his hand on the number of care home workers who have sadly died of the virus.

Sophie Smith and her husband Jack had given up hope of ever becoming parents to their own children, after spending six years desperately trying to conceive. The couple, from Berkhamsted, Hertfordshire, went through five devastating miscarriages and two ectopic pregnancies that required both of her fallopian tubes to be removed - leaving Sophie unable to carry her own baby. But their despair turned to joy when -year-old Sophieaposs best friend, Emiliana Hall, , stepped in and offered to carry a baby for the couple. The mum-of-two was pregnant with her son Theo, now two, at the time but was determined to give her friends aposthe greatest gt of leapos. And now, Sophieaposs dreams have come true as her bestie gave birth to baby Leo James on Tuesday, March . Sophie, a fashion buyer, said: It feels like a dream that we are finally parents - we have been waiting for this moment for so long. Nothing can prepare you for the immense pain caused when trying to conceive but my friends and husband never left my side throughout my never ending grief. We canapost thank Em enough for helping us become parents - it has been a surreal experience.  Weaposve been by her side every step of the way, even when in the labour room which was insane to witness him being born. Em started crying first which then set us all off and when I saw him for the first time - my maternal instincts immediately kicked in. After he was weighed, I was first to do skin-on-skin and it just felt so right - we couldnapost imagine our le without him. I have been waiting for the moment Jack becomes a daddy for the  years we have been together - our journey has been tough but we are so grateful for our Em - she is my angel. The past six years have made us resilient so we arenapost fazed by the sleep deprivation - we are enjoying every single second. Emiliana had a caesarean to ensure the first-time parents didnapost miss the birth. Sophie said: It was a shock to me when Em offered and it took me a few months to believe her. She will be Leoaposs special Aunty Em who we will always be grateful for. Emiliana, who is a hypnobirthing teacher, said: I thought about being a surrogate for two months before proposing the idea to Sophie as it isnapost the type of thing you can say and go back on.  I wanted to make sure I was serious and that my partner James, who is a travel agent, was happy for me to go ahead with it. I think him seeing Jack in so much emotional pain over the years has made it an easy decision for him too. After all our years of growing up together and causing mischief, it has suddenly got really serious but theyaposre going to make the most amazing parents!

The -year-oldaposs condition had at one point been so serious she was told to say goodbye to her husband Craig and children Imogen,  and Daniel, . As she watched four other patients die, she even asked nursesshe was next. Thankfully, she is now the first patient with the deadly virus to be discharged from the ICU unit at the Conquest Hospital in Hastings. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here The civil servant, who was also told she had developed pneumonia, said nothing was too much for the NHS staff who treated her. I can never thank the nurses enough, she said. I could see some of them almost passing out because the PPE was unbearable. But they never once made a fuss or complained. I just thought oh my gosh they are doing all this for us. They are not only providing medical support but they are providing that human, personal and emotional support you need. It was constant care, holding my hand and giving me reassurance. I asked them a few times was I dying and they took the time to sit with me and reassure me that I was OK. The staff even lined up to clap her away when she was well enough to be discharged. I just remember feeling overwhelmed and the staff were waving and cheering me on, she continued.  It should have been me applauding them. They are heroes. Ruth, who had no underlying health conditions, says she first fell ill on March  when she developed a cough. After she was sent home from her job at the Department for Work and Pensions, she developed a fever and began self-isolating at home. But a week later her breathing became so bad that her worried husband dialled . Craig says I was wheezing and it sounded like I was having an asthma attack, she says.  I had no time to say goodbye to my kids who were asleep when the ambulance came. I was in total shock. She was admitted to the ICU after testing positive for Covid-, and hours later, staff told her they would have to put her in an induced coma and that now was the time to make any phone calls. I called Craig but he didnapost answer so I had to ask the doctors to tell him I loved him and the kids, Ruth continued. It was terrying. Ruth says she is amazed by the compassion nurses showed to those patients she was treated alongside who did not make it. They were all alone, she said. The nurses held their hands and were talking to them before and after. They were speaking so kindly. Their compassion really amazed me because it must have been so hard for them. It was heartbreaking and I spent a lot of time crying. After eventually being transferred to a high dependence unit and then a ward, Ruth was finally allowed home on April . She says the experience has left her feeling absolutely drained and that she sometimes wakes up with nightmares. I am struggling to sleep and am waking up with nightmares. I become very emotional sporadically, she said. But I am relieved to be at home and I feel so lucky to be alive.

The shower - an annual event from April - - is to peak tonight, producing around  meteors per hour, and people have been sitting out in their gardens accompanied by duvets, hot chocolate and iPhones. At the same time, the billionaire Musk has launched a series of satellites aimed to providing a global internet service and between the two thereaposs been plenty to keep people watching the skies. Shona Moss, , said she and her partner got their six-year-old son out of bed at midnight and within  seconds the most amazing meteor Iaposve ever seen drew an arc across the sky. James Smith said: Man, the Lyrid meteor shower is spectacular and I‚Äôve only been looking  minutes!!While Martina said: What a magical sky tonight! There are plenty of them!! While Jamesh said at around .am: Just spotted an amazing meteor over Milton Keynes! Mesmerising. For some it was a less awe-inspiring experience and more tranquil.Phil Sloman said: Saw one meteor while watching the skies. Very peaceful experience with the sound of Tawny Owls in the nearby woods for accompaniment. Heading to bed now. The Lyrids are one of the oldest known meteor showers, having been observed for over , years.But with much of the world faced with uncertainty during coronavirus lockdown, it seems to have taken on more precedence this year - and people are appreciating the people around them as much whataposs going on in the sky.Brian Hill tweeted: Lovely hour in my back garden in Belfast with my we watching the meteor shower just under the starry plough. Many people pointed out that thanks to less air pollution, due to far fewer people heading out to work each day for the last month, the sky seemed clearer.Added to the meteors was the UFO-like lights also racing through the night sky, but these were not a natural phenomenon: rather a constellation of thousands of satellites designed to provide low-cost broadband internet service. The ¬£ billion Starlink project has seen batches of satellites launched into the orbit  at a time, with a previous launch in late March and another tonight.They have been spotted all week in the UK due to their low Earth orbit, creating plenty of confusion on Twitter between Starlink and the meteor shower.One user with the handle @elliecov expressed her delight at spotting a aposmeteor showerapos, only to be left disappointed. First time I‚Äôve ever seen a meteor shower and my inner child feels fulfilled that I finally got wish upon a shooting star, she tweeted.  However, later when she realised what sheaposd actually seen, she said: I‚Äôve just found out the meteor shower was in fact Starlink satellites realigning and now I‚Äôm sad. But others were more impressed by both phenomenon and the chance to see them together. Twitter user Pamela said: Sitting in the garden with my sister with our duvets and a cup of hot chocolate watching the Starlink satellites and Lyrid meteor shower. Have seen   satellites so far in Glasgow, amazing. Love me some stargazing. While Scott Pottie wrote: Me and my  year old son watched them. He was so excited. Peter Laws added: Kids and I lay out in the garden for an hour under duvets and watched the #starlinksattelites. Saw them so clearly. While Han OaposConnor tweeted: Up early tomorrow but cheeky hour or so stargazing well spent. Great to see Starlink satellites, a beautul view of Venus and even lucky enough to see a meteor. The meteors come from leftover particles from Comet C  G Thatcher, and bits from broken asteroids. ‚ÄúWhen comets come around the sun, they leave a dusty trail behind them, NASA has explained. ‚ÄúEvery year the Earth passes through these debris trails, which allows the bits to collide with our atmosphere where they disintegrate to create fiery and colourful streaks in the sky.‚Äù

story: NewsMans work from home blunder as everyone can see x-rated content on laptopA hilariously awkward email exchange between two colleagues has gone viral on social media but its not quite what it seemsShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  APR NewsShocked and worried man working in his office" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email With a number of countries still on lockdown due to the coronavirus pandemic, many people are currently working from home.Undoubtedly this means many will take advantage of the opportunity to stay in bed all day or wear hoodies to work everyday. But one man decided to do something a bit more x-rated while out of the office. The man, known only as Callum, appeared to suffer a rather embarrassing work from home blunder after a colleague informed him they could all see what was on his laptop screen.And it turned out that in between doing his regular tasks, Callum had been watching porn. A screenshot of an email sent to him about the incident was shared on Reddit. It was posted by a user known as Cheesywheelchair who said: Work is definitely the right time... The email, sent by a man named Gary is surprising though, as it doesnapost criticise Callum for not working, but instead provides some helpful advice. Gary wrote: Morning Callum, hope you feeling better. Can see youaposre logged in via remote access.  Your screen here is visible and we can all see you watching porn in between enquiries. If you go to the top of the screen there is a menu bar, one of the icons will have a black screen option,you click on this it will blank out your office machine, so you can continue in private. The post went viral, garnering more than , up votes and over  comments.
