title: revealed-uk-airports-biggest-drop-traffic-since-lockdown-started
story: Since thelockdown was announced on March , ordinary le has come to a standstill and a dramatic number of flights have been grounded.The UK Government recently requested that any Britishnationals still abroad for business or short-term purposeshome immediately.The Foreign and Commonwealth Officehas since advised Brits against all but absolutely essential travel worldwide, with restrictions applying for an indefinite period.Many countries around the world have now closed their borders to foreigners and may restrict travel without any notice.As a result of these unprecedented measures, flight traffic in the UK has been in sharp decline since the lockdown was first announced - with some airports seeing a reduction of  per cent.These are the airports that have seen the biggest weekly reduction in flights, according to data from flightradar:The data looks at the drop in weekly flights between the week ending March and the week ending April .Cardf, Leeds Bradford Airport and Newquay recorded no flights at all in the week ending April , representing a drop of  per cent.Gatwick, which saw  flights in the week ending March , saw just  flights take off in the week ending April .Lockdown measures around the world have seen air and motor traffic fall dramatically, leading to a reduction in air pollution in many cities.Some cities have seen nitrogen dioxidelevels fall by up to  per cent since last year, analysis shows.Environmental campaigners hope that the drop will encourage permanent action on pollution even when lockdown measures are eased.Scientists are also exploring a possible link between the severity of air pollution and the chances of dying from coronavirus.However, medical scientists say it is still too early to confirm a definite link between the severity of Covid- and pollution in areas where patients live.

title: yousaf-says-given-up-leonard-scottish-labour-islamophobia
story: The Justice Secretary said the Scottish Labour leader had ldquono credibility on the issuegiven at least one high-profile investigation had now dragged on more than two years.Mr Yousaf told BBC Radio Scotland: ldquoI have to say Irsquove given up even speaking to Richard Leonard on this matter.In March , Labour suspended Dumfries  Galloway councillor Jim Dempster after he made an Islamophobic comment about Mr Yousaf, who was then SNP transport minister.Cllr Dempster had referred to Mr Yousaf being invisible ldquounder his burka.Mr Leonard said at the time Cllr Dempster that had ldquounreservedly apologised for the hurt and offence caused, and there would be ldquoan inquiry and a due process will be followed.However, despite Cllr Dempster admitting the remark, Labour has still to conclude its inquiry.Asked about the case, Mr Yousaf told Good Morning Scotland he had no faith in Scottish Labour to act and urged new UK leader Sir Keir Starmer to settle the matter.He said: ldquoRichard Leonard has no credibility on this issue any more. I would urge Keir Starmer, the new leader of the Labour party in the UK, to process these complaints, to take decisive action, not just against Councillor Jim Dempster, but many others.He went on: ldquoIn terms of Richard Leonard,he thinks hersquos done enough and can now just pass over responsibility, and duck responsibility, then he should at the very least release all the correspondence that he sent to the UK Labour party on this issue demanding action is being action, so that we can actually judge the fact hersquos made an effort.ldquoI have to say Irsquove given up even speaking to Richard Leonard on this matter, or indeed raising it with the Scottish Labour party, because itrsquos clear to me that they donrsquot take these matters at all seriously.Earlier on the same show, Mr Leonard was asked about Mr Yousafrsquos previously saying he should be ashamed to show his face at anti-racism rallies given the Dempster case delay.Mr Leonard said: ldquoI am always happy to speak to Humza Yousaf about where we are with this case. I am frustrated as well that itrsquos taken as long as it has.ldquoItrsquos not clear to me why it has taken as long as it has.ldquoHe has been suspended and does not play an active part in the Labour party or the Labour group where hersquos an elected councillor.Pressed on a timetable for resolving the case, Mr Leonard said: ldquoIt needs to be resolved, in my view, timeously. Look, for the le of me I donrsquot know why it has taken as long as it has.ldquoIt ought to have been dealt with more speedily, but the consideration of that case rests in the hands of the party at a UK level.Mr Leonard then tried to change the focus of the interview back to coronavirus.He said: ldquoI have to say, some of these issues are a source of frustration to me, but in the end we are dealing with a national crisis where people are dying, and the effect of this pandemic ought to be the thing which is first and foremost in our discussions and debates.ldquoItrsquos whatrsquos driving me, itrsquos what Irsquom spending all my waking hours dealing with, not with some of the internal grievance and disciplinary procedures of the Labour party.Mr Leonard was also asked about readmitting nine Labour councillors who were suspended from the party in May  for working with the Tories on Aberdeen City Council.Mr Leonardrsquos new deputy, Dumbarton MSP Jackie Baillie, and the Shadow Scottish Secretary Ian Murray have both called for the lsquoAberdeen Ninersquo to be let back into the party.Asked why the matter had gone on for years and whether he was minded to readmit them, Mr Leonard again deferred to Labour in London: ldquoThe case of the Aberdeen councillors rests with the national constitutional committee of the Labour party.ldquoThere is a due process which needs to be followed and I am frustrated that it has taken as long as it has, but there is a due process which needs to be followed.ldquoTheir case is resting with the national constitutional committee of the Labour party.Askedthe committee was fit for purpose given the delay, Mr Leonard said: ldquoI am also frustrated it has taken as long as it has to get this resolved.ldquoWe understand that there is frustration faced by people in the Labour party in Aberdeen, members of that group in Aberdeen, but also this has wider implications too about how we go about our business as a party and itrsquos important that we give due process and donrsquot prejudice the hearings that will take place at some point in the future.In November, Mr Leonard admitted it was ldquoentirely unsatisfactory the case had taken so long, but refused to get involved, saying it was a matter for Labourrsquos national constitutional committee.Askedhe ought to be involved, he said: ldquoNo, I donrsquot think I should be. I think itrsquos right therersquos a separation between the political leadership of the party and political representatives of the party and those people who are directly elected to carry out those investigations.It prompted Mr Yousaf at the time to accuse Mr Leonard of a ldquocomplete lack of leadership.

title: coronavirus-scotland-forgotten-construction-industry-calls-support
story: TheScottish Building Federationsaid a survey of its members revealedmore than three-quarters have seen all cash flow stop, whilst  per cent have furloughed at least % of their staff.Despite this, the industry ndashwhich employs over , people and makes up a substantial slice of the economy ndash says it has receivedno specic support.Official analysis has warned Scotlands economy could shrink by a third during the coronavirus lockdown, with the potential for ldquolong lasting impacts.:Coronavirus in Scotland: Care home deaths almost equal those in hospitalsVaughan Hart, managing director of SBF, said most of its members have heeded advice to stop working to protectstaff and the wider community.He said: ldquoWe welcome the Scottish Governmentrsquos second phase of funding which includes a fund of poundm to support businesses in financial distress due to Covid-.ldquoOther heavily-impacted sectors which were initially advised to close have rightly received signicant support and other industries have now received bespoke support packages from the Scottish Government. "Construction seems to have been forgotten despite being one of the most crucial sectors to the Scottish economy."Our sector employs over , people and is % of the Scottish economy but many of our members are struggling. "They urgently need specic support from governmentthey are to survive the current crisis and be in a position to help rebuild the Scottish economy when it ends.:Coronavirus: Charity demands action as Scottish care home deaths more than double in a weekThe SBF said the retail, hospitality and leisure sectors have been designated ldquoheavily-impacted and benefit from % rates relief as well as further grant funding.Its survey of more than  members indicated that only % of construction firms are eligible for the pound, grant funding offered through the Small Business Bonus Schemeand Rural Rate Relief .It found cashflowhas stopped entirely at % of firms, while% want similar support to that offered to retail, hospitality and leisure businesses.The vast majorityof sites controlled by SBF members are closed in compliance with the guidance issued by the Scottish Government, with the remainder falling under the lsquoessential workrsquo category.Elsewhere, figures showretail sales have plummeted by % in the last two weeks of March .

title: keir-starmer-accuses-uk-govt-repeatedly-slow-response-pandemic-first-digital-pmqs
story: The new Labour leader and Foreign Secretary Mr Raab - deputising for Boris Johnson as the Prime Minister continued his recovery from Covid- - faced each other in a sparsely attended House of Commons as the majority of MPs participated remotely.Sir Keir questioned the Governments progress towards its target of carrying out , tests a day by the end of the month and claimed that opportunities to acquire personal protective equipment [PPE] from British firms had been missed.He said: "There is a pattern emerging here. We were slow into lockdown, slow on testing, slow on protective equipment and now slow to take up these offers from British firms.":Coronavirus in Scotland: Hospital death toll breaches , as , dischargedMr Raab told him that the Government was guided by scientic advisers.He said thatSir Keir "thinks he knows better than they do, with the benefit of hindsight, then thats his decision".Mr Raab said , British businesses had responded to a call for assistance on PPE and they had all received a response, with some , followed up where it was "sensible"they had equipment with the required specication and volume.He said it was an "incredibly dficult and competitive international environment" to source PPE from overseas.On testing, the latest figures showed that less than half of the available capacity was being used and fewer than , tests had been carried out in a -hour period.Sir Keir questioned how the Government would ramp that up to , tests a day in just eight days time - particularly as some care workers and NHS staff could only be testedthey could drive to a site.UK ministers have repeatedly insisted the target will be met and Mr Raab insisted that "those tests will be crucial not just in terms of controlling the virus but allowing the country to move to the next phase".:Coronavirus: Charity demands action as Scottish care home deaths more than double in a weekHe said mobile labs were now being used with the Army also helping to get tests to where they were needed.Mr Raab told MPs Mr Johnson continued to recover from coronavirus at Chequers and was in "good spirits".In other developments -*An RAF plane landed at Brize Norton from Turkey in the early hours of Wednesday, after being sent to collect a shipment of PPE - including badly-needed surgical gown.*The Government continued to face questions about its participation in EU schemes to secure vital equipment with Brussels saying there had been "ample opportunity" for the UK to join in.*More than  frontline NHS staff were confirmed to have died during the coronavirus pandemic*Professor Robin Shattock from Imperial Colleges Department of Infectious Disease, said a coronavirus vaccine may be available for front-line workers and the most vulnerable by late winter*Cancer Research UK warned that more than , new cancer cases could be going undetected each week as fewer people go to see their GP and also due to practitioners reluctance to send patients to hospital due to the risk of Covid- infection.*Labour said  companies had approached them to claim that offers of help to supply PPE had been ignored. They included Issa Exchange Ltd in Birmingham which said it offered a quarter of a million aprons and masks, Network Medical Products in Ripon, which says it can provide , face visors per week and CQM Learning, which says it can provide , face shields per day.

title: coronavirus-uk-at-peak-covid-19
story: Speaking in the House of Commons this afternoon Matt Hancock said the country had now reached the peak of the disease, but said there would not be changes to the current lockdown strategy.He also confirmed that  social care staff have died having contracted Covid- while working in nursing homes and care settings.Mr Hancock told MPs that five things had to be achieved "before we relax any social distancing rules or make changes", including ensuring the NHS is able to cope, and continuing to see the daily number of people who de from the virus falling "consistently".He said: "We are at the peak. But before we relax any social distancing rules, or make changes to that we have set out five tasks that have to be met. First that the NHS can continue to cope second that the operational challenges have been met third, that the daily death rate falls sustainably and consistently fourth that the rate of infection is decreasing, and most importantly fth, that there is no risk of a second peak."The minister said that while the government is still working towards its UK-wide goal of carrying out , tests a day by the end of the month, he admitted that "demand has thus far been lower than expected" although the "expansion of capacity is ahead of plan".The Government is now expected to increase the categories of workers eligible to be tested in an attempt to meet its goal, as well as increase the number of mobile testing units available and send out at-home testing kits for those unable to reach testing sites.It has been suggested that supermarket workers could be among those offered testing.Shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth demanded that staff be given testing "at a local NHS site or by mobile unit, as it is clearly ludicrous to expect care workers to travel miles to drive-thru test centres."Former labour leader Jeremy Corbyn also said the government was "nowhere near" the level of testing needed.Mr Hancock responded: "We were one of the first countries in the world to develop a test, we rapidly increase the number of tests from  at the start of March to , thats a multiple of five times during March, and now going up further. This is an area where weve had our foot on the gas, all the way through."Meanwhile the Scottish Conservatives have urged the Scottish Government to take the lead on mobile testing, particularly in remote areas.

title: sketch-virtual-pmqs---victory-floral-wallpaper-chintzy-curtains
story: The nation was offered an array of flaring nostrils, floral wallpaper, carefully arranged bookshelves and chintzy curtains as MPs called in from the comfort of their bedrooms, lounges and kitchens some, no doubt, below the camera line were still wearing their shorts, leggings and pyjama bottoms.The normally crammed Commons bear-pit, full of noise, energy and anger, was more like a sunny Sunday afternoon in the park with MPs leisurely sprawling on sparsely populated, silent leather benches. All that was missing was birdsong and a picnic hamper.Question-time began pleasantly enough with Dominic Raab, the First Secretary, praising the heroes of the NHS and the Speaker wishing the conspicuously absent Boris a full and speedy recovery.:Keir Starmer accuses UK Govt of being slow in its response to pandemicKeir Starmer, with his hair slicked back, began his debut at the PMQs dispatch box, stressing how he wanted to lead a constructive opposition but then began slowly to deconstruct the Governmentrsquos response to the coronavirus outbreak.ldquoThere is a pattern emerging here, declared the new chief comrade. ldquoWe were slow into lockdown, slow on testing, slow on protective equipment and now slow to take up these offers from British firms."Raab, who was doing a fine impersonation of a talking wardrobe, suddenly gave the Labour knight his death stare, taken aback by theto the political sniping of old.Stressing how the Government had moved every step of the way in line with the boffinsrsquo advice, the First Secretary snipped: ldquoIf he thinks he knows better than they do, with the benefit of hindsight, then thats his decision". So there.First up for a virtual question was Conservative grandee David Mundell. Or not. The Speaker stood up to inform MPs: ldquoUnable to connect. Not for the first time, one or two opponents doubtless thought.The SNPrsquos champion Ian Blackford had better luck and implored the talking wardrobe that, come on, now was the time for a universal basic income so that ldquono one is left behind.: Coronavirus in Scotland: Hospital death toll breaches , as , dischargedThe more eagle-eyed viewer might have spied in the background of the Highlanderrsquos mansion among the footballs a card, bearing what looked remarkably like a Hibernian  Rangers  scoreline. Surely not.The First Sec peering upwards at the two giant screens hovering ominously overhead reverted to first principles and stressed the ldquoUKwide effort to ensure as ldquoone United Kingdom we defeat the coronavirus.High Tory Peter Bone had a dig at the banks but appeared to be continuing his attack after he had been muted on screen much to the merriment of MPs.Arguably the most interesting question came from the Plaid Cymru leaderene Liz Savile Roberts, who, pointing out how the pandemic had been tackled on a four-nation approach, askedthis meant that when it came to lting the restrictions, this should be done on a basis of unanimity. In other words, would Wales of Scotland have a veto.The stand-in PM looked up, looked down and decided not to answer the question. He again stressed the co-operation of the four nations and hoped the cross-country collaboration would continue in the ldquosecond phase.It was a blatant dodge. When it comes to PMQs, some things, virtually or otherwise, donrsquot change.

title: coronavirus-scotland-snp-mp-calls-pub-landlords-given-rent-freeze
story: Tommy Sheppard, who represents Edinburgh East, has written to Belhaven Greene King, Pub Taverns, Hawthorn Leisure Ltd and Trust Inns Ltd - calling for the firms to put in place a rent freeze for their tenant licensees during the Covid- enforced closure.Mr Sheppards constituency includes a large number of pubs and bars owned by the big companies - and is pressing them to follow Admiral Taverns example after the company cancelled rents due in April.He said: "There have been a number of supports put in place for pubs which I welcome, but the reality is thatrents are not cancelled, landlords will face tens of thousands of pounds in rent arrears with very little prospect of paying these debts off.:Coronavirus in Scotland: Edinburghs economy set for poundm hit after festivals axed"Rents are based on turnover so it is dficult to justy continuing to collect rents when there is no turnover due to all pubs being closed."Pubs are a vital part of Edinburghrsquos culture and economy and I would hope that pub companies would lead by example helping to ensure that many of our favourite pubs survive the current crisis and are able to spring back into action once it ends.Rodney Taylor, owner of Drury Street Bar  Kitchen in Glasgow, earlier this week warned there is a "kicking time bomb" under the licensed trade - with a number of businesses missing out on emergency funding.:Coronavirus crisis: Glasgow pub trade is lsquoticking time bombrsquoCAMRArsquos Scotland director, Sarah Crawford, said: ldquoPublicans shouldnrsquot be being charged rentthey have no turnover because they have to stay closed to help prevent the spread of coronavirus."Pub company bosses must now do the right thing and cancel rent payments for their tied pub tenants, so our locals can survive this crisis, re-open and thrive in the months and years ahead.

title: carmichael disappointed by governments immigration policy
story: Orkney and Shetland MP Alistair Carmichael has voiced disappointment at the lack of change in the government‚Äôs post-EU immigration policy in light of the coronavirus crisis.Mr Carmicheal was reacting to the release of guidance for employers earlier this month which detailed how, as of January , , free movement will end and the UK will introduce a points-based immigration system.In the guidance put forward those wanting to move to the UK will be required to earn  points to be eligible to apply for a visa. Points will be awarded for such things as being able to speak English, having a job already lined up and meeting appropriate skill levels. They will also have to meet a minimum salary threshold, which the guidance informs is generally ¬£,, although a lower salary might be accepted in some circumstances.Under this new system, low-skilled workers will not be able to receive visas to live and work in the UK.The new system however, will not apply to EU citizens already living in the UK by December , this year. They will be eligible to apply to the EU Settlement Scheme.Highlighting the impact immigrants have had in the fight against coronavirus, Mr Carmichael called on the government to rethink its plans and support key workers.‚ÄúWhen the immigration proposals were first announced earlier in the year I called them short-sighted and a risk to the long-term future of island communities,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúWe are already seeing the potential harm we risk to our communities and our country. It is time that the government started rethinking its plans.‚ÄúAround the UK we are seeing the positive impact that immigrants are having as key workers in the fight against coronavirus. That the government has not reflected on this at all in developing its advice on immigration policy is disappointing. If immigrants can be essential workers in our country‚Äôs time of crisis, then they deserve our support to remain here afterwards.‚ÄùMr Carmichael added: ‚ÄúLast week I joined my colleague Christine Jardine in calling for foreign nationals working in the NHS in this crisis to have the right to remain. title: diabetes scotland support groups go digital in response to covid 19
story: People living with diabetes in Orkney are being encouraged to join new online groups, as well as yoga and mindfulness sessions, run by Diabetes Scotland while they are unable to access their usual support for wellbeing during lockdown.There are over , people living with diabetes in Scotland, including over , in Orkney, and the charity is encouraging everyone living with the condition to pay extra attention to their physical, emotional and mental health at this time, while assuring them that they are on hand to offer support.Using online video app, Zoom, they launched digital peer support chats at the beginning of April with a group for people with type  diabetes and a group for young adults with type  diabetes currently running.They say that groups will be kept small to allow conversation to flow more easily, with the idea being to bring together people going through similar experiences so they can offer each other support and friendship, all from the safety of their own homes.Responding to demand, the charity hopes to offer a number of dferent groups for people of ious ages living with or caring for someone with type , type  or any other type of diabetes.Mindfulness and yoga via online video link is also being introduced this month with twice-weekly sessions run by Zen yoga and mindfulness teacher Donna Booth of Vitality Retreat based in Wick.‚ÄúStress can affect your blood sugar levels,‚Äù said Donna.‚ÄúMindfulness and yoga are one way to help lower stress levels. The yoga postures we‚Äôll be doing in the sessions bring some easy, relaxing movements for the body. Mindfulness allows us to be in the present moment rather than worrying about the past or future which can make it easier to accept change and to make the adjustments necessary to feel well.‚ÄùAngela Mitchell, national director of Diabetes Scotland, said: ‚ÄúWe are proud to have over  local groups serving communities across Scotland. Of course, not everyone can attend a group, especially now when we‚Äôre advised against all but essential trips out of our homes.‚ÄúWe had already planned to introduce digital peer support groups this year but due to social distancing measures we brought our launch forward.¬† Many people at home are feeling isolated and,you‚Äôre also managing a long-term condition like diabetes, it can be even more challenging. We want to support people with diabetes in any way that we can at this time. As well as online peer support groups, yoga and mindfulness, we also have a helpline, online forum and the Diabetes Scotland team can be reached as we continue to work from home.‚ÄùGroups meet in private sessions over Zoom. Peer support group times are still flexible while a schedule is created to meet demand. Mindfulness and yoga will run on Wednesdays at pm and Fridays at pm for the next four weeks.Anyone who is interested in joining either peer support or mindfulness and yoga should email scotland@diabetes.org.uk to be invited to a group and given instructions on how to access Zoom .Guidance regarding diabetes and coronavirus can be found at www.diabetes.org.uk coronavirus or by calling the Diabetes Scotland helpline on    or emailing¬†helpline@diabetes.org.ukcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: new guidance issued for home learning
story: The Scottish Government has issued new guidance to support the home learning of children and young people during the new term.It aims to build on the signicant amount of positive work that has already been undertaken by teachers and education professionals across Scotland to support learning at home, as well as the advice and resources that are already available.The guidance covers three main areas:Deputy First Minister John Swinney said: ‚ÄúGiven the unprecedented circumstances, we cannot predict when schools in Scotland will reopen. title: no recreational visits to north isles airfields during covid 19
story: Orkney Islands Council is reminding pilots that recreational flights should not be made to North Isles airfields during the coronavirus crisis.Recreational flights involving council-owned and operated airfields in the North Isles have reportedly taken place on at least two occasions over the past few weeks.The airfields are currently closed to recreational visits by aircraft in line with Scottish Government emergency measures to restrict non-essential travel. In addition, recreational flying should not take place below  feet in the air space immediately around the airfields.The restrictions are in place to slow the spread of COVID- infection, save lives and protect the NHS.Brian Archibald, OIC‚Äôs head of marine services, engineering and transportation, said: ‚ÄúHigher risk recreational activities such as flying, yachting or mountaineering are actively discouraged and could be regarded as irresponsible during the pandemic.‚ÄúIn the event of an accident, the emergency and services and NHS could face considerable added pressure at a time when so much effort is going into the local and nationwide response to COVID-.‚ÄùThe airfields were reportedly used without prior permission being sought. Pilots are required to do this under the terms of the council‚Äôs license to operate issued by the Civil Aviation Authority.North Isles airfields remain open for Loganair flights, currently operating a reduced twice-daily service, for any medical emergencies, for the transportation of medical samples or tests, and for the delivery of medication and freight when required.Fire crews at the airfields are continuing to train and provide cover when flights are notied # to ensure that the communities they serve can receive the leline services they depend upon.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: coronavirusSSEN extends Priority Services Register during pandemicApril ,  at : am vw, px"  Scottish and Southern Electricity Networksis extending the support it provides to those most vulnerable by expanding the eligibility of its Priority Services Registerto include customers at increased risk of severe illness during the coronavirus pandemic.A team from the power supplier is also working to proactively contact customers who may be at risk of social isolation during the lockdown period, checking in on their welfare and signposting to further community support where required.Customers categorised at ‚Äòhigh risk‚Äô and ‚Äòextremely high risk‚Äô of severe illness from coronavirus are now eligible to sign up for additional support under the company#s . This includes those following government guidelines who have received a letter from the NHS to socially shield for a -week period.SSEN is also offering a friendly ear to PSR-registered customers over , with a new team set up specically to call them during the pandemic, check on their welfare and signpost to local community support groups where required.Using SSEN‚Äôs customer mapping tool, which provides detailed demographic information about the communities SSEN serves, , customers have been identied who may benefit from this additional support, including lone pensioners and those at high risk of social isolation.SSEN#s Social Obligations Manager, Julie Walker, said ‚ÄúThe coronavirus pandemic has changed things for us all, and with everyone doing their bit to ensure they keep themselves, their friends, family and loved ones safe during the pandemic, here at SSEN we continue to focus on ensuring those most vulnerable are supported by our dedicated teams.‚ÄúBy expanding the eligibility for our PSR we want to offer some reassurance in these worrying times, and so I‚Äôd encourage anyone who thinks that they, a family member, friend or neighbour could benefit from the extra help that is on offer, to get in touch, we‚Äôd love to hear from them.‚ÄúWe‚Äôre also very aware that a lot of our elderly customers rely on their regular lunch clubs and coffee mornings for social interaction, and with these postponed at the moment they may not be having as much contact with the outside world. title: virtual house of commons procedure welcomed
story: MP for Orkney and Shetland Alistair Carmichael has welcomed the announcement that representatives are to be able to quiz ministers virtually.The move, which is the first of its kind in the House of Commons# -year history,has been agreed upon by the House of Commons authorities.Approval has been given to allow up to  MPs at any one time to take part in proceedings virtually, while around  could remain in the chamber under social distancing rules.There is an expectation that fewer MPs will be present in the Chamber as many will have dficulties getting to parliament. MPs are being encouraged to work virtually, especially as any MP in the Chamber will be treated the same as one appearing virtually and would only be called to speaklisted.The step towards a ‚Äòhybrid‚Äô House was taken by the House of Commons Commission in a bid to keep democracy going during the coronavirus crisis.The historic measures will still need the approval of MPs when theyfrom Easter recess on April .The hybrid model was developed at speed and chosen as an achievable first step towards a virtual Parliament ‚Äì having the benefit of meeting current technological capacity.Orkney and Shetland MP, Alistair Carmichael said: ‚ÄúA hybrid parliament like this is better than no parliament at all. This can only be an interim measure however, on the way to a wholly virtual parliament.‚ÄúI will keep working with the government and all parties to ensure that all parts of the United Kingdom are given a voice and that all political views are heard.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. laps of his garden before his th birthday on April .Chief of the Defence Staff, General Sir Nick Carter singled Capt Moore out for praise at Wednesdayrsquos daily coronavirus press conference, challenge which I firmly believe we will defeat together.At the beginning of the Second World War, Capt Moore enlisted into the eighth battalion of the Duke of Wellingtonrsquos Regiment , an infantry title: talking sport with jim tait 28
story: There has been much talk over whether highly paid sportsmen and women, especially footballers, should be giving up a substantial part of their income during the coronavirus crisis.The Players Together scheme, launched by Liverpool captain Jordan Henderson and other English Premiership players, is designed to give help to the NHS and is admirable.In Scotland the first club to take the initiative was Heart of Midlothian, which revealed over a fortnight ago that it would be asking all staff to consider a  per cent pay cut.Experienced forward Steven Naismith immediately stated he would be willing to forego half of his wages. Considering his past record as a caring inidual, including his efforts to help the homeless, that was not really surprising.But apart from manager Daniel Stendl, who waived his salary, others at the Edinburgh club appeared reluctant to follow Naismith‚Äôs example. Reports later suggested that no other Hearts player would be asked to take more than a  per cent reduction.Also last week it was claimed that Scotland manager Steve Clarke had accepted a  per cent cut, simply meaning his salary would go down from ¬£, to ¬£,.In England the men‚Äôs and women‚Äôs international bosses Gareth Southgate and Phil Neville apparently agreed to take  per cent less. In the former‚Äôs case he would still be pocketing ¬£. million while Neville would get ¬£,.At club level south of the border the situation is very inconsistent. Some managers, such as David Moyes, Eddie Howe and Graham Potter have volunteered to take a cut while Pep Guardiola donated a million euros to help fight the outbreak in Spain. There was a terrible poignancy to Guardiola‚Äôs generosity a few days later when it was reported that his -year-old mother had died as a result of the virus in Barcelona.But while most Premiership clubs have placed most non-playing staff on some kind of temporary leave, some receiving  per cent of their salary through the government‚Äôs job retention scheme, the situation with the majority of players is still unclear.This is a dficult situation and UK health minister Matt Hancock ruffled some feathers when he suggested that well-off footballers should consider doing more to help.Some journalists have even criticised Hancock, saying he was completely out of touch with what was actually happening. That was unfair. The minister was not speaking about the game in general, where players at lower-level clubs are paid a pittance compared with those at the top. He was merely highlighting the fact that many could easily survive with no pay at all for the foreseeable future.To put this in perspective, most players at Premiership level are earning several million a year, an increase of roughly two and a half times what they took home six years ago. A high proportion are on more than ¬£, a week.At the top of the tree are Manchester United goalkeeper David De Gea and Man City midfielder Kevin De Bruyne, who are on over ¬£ million and ¬£ million respectively.Even a player I confess to never having heard of, Tanguy Ndombele of Tottenham Hotspur, is reportedly bagging ¬£. million a year.In the Championship the average annual pay is considerably less, around ¬£, a year or ¬£, a week. And in the lower League Two it drops to ¬£ or ¬£ weekly, not all that much above the national average.During the current situation all these figures need to be taken into consideration. We should have no issue with lower-paid players still getting  per cent of their wages for doing nothing. They, like everyone , still have bills to pay.But for the multi-millionaires to grumble about being hit is about as hard to take as the coronavirus pandemic itself.: : : : : : : :No decision has yet been made about whether the football leagues in the UK will be completed, whenever the action begins again.In Scotland it has been proposed in some quarters that the title should just be handed to Celtic, as the Glasgow side had an almost unassailable lead when play stopped.Now a director of the other half of the Old Firm has suggested thatthat happened, their rivals would only be able to claim ‚Äúeight and a half‚Äù in a rowthey were crowned champions.Personally I feel that this season‚Äôs scheduled fixtures should be played out, however long it takes. Only then should the - action start, evenit means a shortened campaign.: : : : : : : :There are currently eight premier ision football clubs in Shetland, all of which have been in existence for dferent s of time.Scalloway are the oldest, dating back to , with Lerwick sides Celtic and Thistle being able to trace their beginnings back to the early part of the th century.Spurs and Ness United both emerged during the s, with Whitedale, Whalsay and Delting joining the senior league more recently.Someone suggested to me that a best XI from each could be selected, to give players and supporters something to ponder over during the current period of uncertainty.There will no doubt be controversy over this, but that‚Äôs what opinion is all about. If anyone would like to submit their thoughts, or their own ideas of what their respective best sides would be, feel free to send them in.Next time I will give you the line-ups, in alphabetical order, from the past  years. Dferent formations may be used, depending on how many defenders, midfielders, or forwards are worthy of inclusion.Email me at j.tait@shetlandtimesyou have any suggestions...

title: coronavirus testing equipment is in the isles

title: football memories best and worst
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineThis week we have two well-known figures from the Skye and Lochalsh league as Sleat and Strath manager DL MacKinnon reflects on a feisty encounter with a north east farmer, while former Portree Juniors coach Phil McCaherty basks in the glory days of the  season. #The dates are fy, but my worst memory and my greatest lesson in le was when I was  years old and playing for Turrf Thistle. It was a Saturday afternoon and the game was a supposed friendly against Rothienorman.‚ÄúBack then I was a hard man, or so I thought! I was up against a burly young farmer-type at centre-half. I had a couple of robust challenges with the lad and he warned me that next time he was having me! Two minutes later he came in from behind and elbowed me in the head, I shrugged it off and instead of walking away I turned around and said: #You ain‚Äôt big enough to put me down, kid.# The next thing I knew, the birds were tweeting around my head and my front teeth were missing!‚ÄúThe game was abandoned and I had to go to the emergency dentist that afternoon and had months of repair work afterward. He had to pay my dental bill and a ¬£ fine. Torquil Mackenzie # a name I will take to my grave!‚Äù ‚ÄúI can#t remember how far back it was but it was a while ago ‚Äî it was a cup final up in Uig against Portree. The game went to extra-time # we had Bruce Neil and Paul Flynn sent off but ended up winning something like -.‚ÄúI remember John ‚ÄòSpod# Macleod scoring a goal and running up the touchline with his hands cupped over his ears to the once noisy Portree support who had given him dogs# abuse during the game. That lives long in the memory!‚Äù ‚ÄúIt won#t come as a surprise to learn the best match was the title-winning game on th August , for many emotional reasons. We had a great campaign that year and had won  out of  games with only three matches remaining. We had to go to Kyleakin away on this date and they were the only team who could catch us in the title challenge.‚ÄúIt was a really nice summer evening and we had a strong team out, although leading striker John Murphy was unavailable through injury which meant young James Pringle played upfront with Craig Brown.‚ÄúKyleakin got out of the blocks quickly and we found ourselves - down early on in the match in front of a big crowd. We settled after that and played some decent stuff but Kyleakin, as usual, were well marshalled by Michael Taylor and we had dficulty in creating clear-cut opportunities. However, with  minutes to go, coach Ian MacLeod and I decided to put youngsters Ian Morrison and Angie MacPherson on each touchline to give us pace and width. The freshness seemed to galvanise us and with  minutes to go, we pulled a goal back through Craig Brown. It seemed the whole match swung on that goal, we picked up some real momentum and Brown scored again to equalise. Then with five minutes to go, we were awarded a penalty with two Kyleakin defenders tackling Brown as he broke into the box. Craig dusted himself down and scored the penalty in off the post # we were delirious on the sidelines. We saw out the game for our first-ever title and then won the remaining two games to make it  wins from  matches # it was a campaign never to be forgotten!‚Äù ‚ÄúIt was my first game in charge, and funnily enough, it was also against Kyleakin. In those campaigns it was always the case that the first game of the season in the Bagshaw League pitted the reigning champions against the team which finished bottom the season before. The bottom club then had to play the runners-up from the previous season and so on, so it was very dficult for the clubs at the bottom to gain any early momentum.‚ÄúWe went down to Kyleakin with a whole bunch of youngsters against the likes of Scott Graham, the Nisbett clan, Darren Wainwright # who were all top players in the league at that time. We lost - and I swearit wasn#t for our young goalie Calum Montgomery making one save it could have been . But in essence, that is where I started from in management. title: a hard time for people of
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineBy John Purser, From the Tobar an Dualchais Kist o‚Äô Riches archiveIt must be a particularly hard time just now for people of faith.Churches, mosques, synagogues and temples are closed. The places where one would most clearly feel the presence of spiritual community are cut off ‚Äì never mind that a pandemic might tempt one to question faith in any deity. Here in the Highlands many still can access the temple of nature, but for some even that temple is essentially out of bounds. We are exiled in our own homes.The theme of exile for some wrong-doing ‚Äì not necessarily a penance but for something perceived as wrong by others ‚Äì is, of course, international, never more so than right now.In the G√†idhealtachd, however, with a history of mass emigration, exile retained a particular relevance well into modern times. So I have gone to Tobar an Dualchais and to Dugald Buchanan, forthere was anyone who understood the agony of spiritual exile and the loneliness of doubt and fear and who grappled with them with profound courage, it was him.Buchanan lived from -, part of the time among the broken men of Rannoch, amongst whom he taught and preached. He was sent by the Society for the Propagation of Christian Knowledge in . He was to be a teacher and a catechist: the catechism was a sort of question and answer method of teaching religion, and its spiritual values.The place Buchanan was sent to was Kinloch Rannoch, and it was in dire need of religion and spiritual values. It was on the edge of Rannoch Moor and was so remote that all the rejects of society ‚Äì outlaws, dispossessed and banished, had gathered there, as far from the law as possible.The broken men of Rannoch were a people destitute and desperate. In ministering to these last vestiges of society, Buchanan was working at its roots, not certainthey were strong or rotten, not certainhis own motives were good or bad.In Buchanan‚Äôs imagery, we engage powerfully with a Dante-esque poetic imagery:Each limb, each member ‚Äì foot and hand, that ever buried were in land or sea or battle-field, shall come together. Loud is the noise among the bones, each coming to its place..In the five verses Robertson has chosen out of one hundred and twenty-one, the last trumpet is heard and the mountains pour out lava.‚ÄúQuench your thirst with it, you horders of gold‚Äù. The sun is in mourning, the moon steeped in blood, the stars are shaken.The poem is terrying, and the hope of salvation depends not upon anything one does oneself, other than placing one‚Äôs trust entirely in God‚Äôs mercy. This is not something you earn: it is something you have to be given. And yet this solemn song, with its simple pentatonic melody, verse after verse, has a beautul and hypnotic power.I am no believer, but this is powerful stuff and not to be lightly dismissed.Confronting the great dilemmas of self-consciousness in his confessional diary and his poetry, Buchanan emerges triumphant and yet sober, thoughtful and grateful. # The Skull # came to Buchanan when, following a young woman‚Äôs burial, he picked up a skull left exposed in Lassintulloch graveyard near Loch Rannoch.Today, the graveyard is as neglected as were the people living there in Buchanan‚Äôs day. Picture him then among the tombstones, looking out northward and the thoughts racing through his mind like the wind through the branches of the surrounding trees as he addresses the skull in his hands.He asks the skullit belonged to a preacher and did the preacher care for his flock or leave them to the care of the fox  Buchanan ends assured that there is hope even in the grave, that the eyes that were once in the skull may shine again as brilliantly as the stars, and that the soul may fly to Christ with the speed of the eagle # to be greeted with love.., back in . I hope that recording will make its way into Tobar an Dualchais one day.I met Willie Matheson just the once long ago ‚Äì Allan insisted I come with him to the hospital where Willie was in a wheelchair, frail but with bright eyes and a welcome smile. I was just at the very beginning of coming to an understanding of Gaelic culture, but there, with my hazy stumbling knowledge, I felt included.Such brief encounters can mean so much. ‚Äì The Sufferings of Christ. The tune is described as ‚ÄúSimple as a Christmas carol, it soon became a favourite throughout Perthshire, being sung to a sweet plaintive air . . .‚Äù., London c..Not the cheeriest of stuff, but realistic and seeking joy against all the odds.The West Highland Free Press online shop is taking no new orders until st May .Sorry for any inconvenience this may cause.

title: easing the lockdown early trials in islands and highlands worth cautious
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineThere should be cautious consideration given to easing lockdown measures in the islands ‚Äì and eventually the Highlands ‚Äì prior to the rest of the country, it was claimed this week.The idea was mooted last weekend by Professor Hugh Pennington, the emeritus professor of bacteriology at Aberdeen University. Prof Pennington said the Western Isles, which at the start of the week had only six confirmed cases of Covid-, could exit the restrictions as a ‚Äútest-bed‚Äù before wider lockdowns were lted.Politicians said the idea was worth considering, but still carried risk.Prof Pennington said: #There could soon be a case for a geographical lting of restrictions # such as in some of the Scottish islands and the Highlands and Grampian.#The Western Isles and Orkney are the obvious candidates to be the test beds for an exit strategy for the country. Travel is restricted because they are islands and have extremely low levels of confirmed cases. You can control access to them and re-open things like shops and churches etc and get back gradually to normal le again.#As for people travelling to the islands it is to be remembered that the vast majority of people have not been affected.‚ÄùHe added that effective testing facilities, which would give a quick result, must first be in place to allow any restrictions to be eased.Western Isles MSP Alasdair Allan said that while the idea had merit, islanders would be alarmedthey felt their health was being compromised as part of an experiment.He said: #It is unfortunate that the language of ‚Äòtestbeds‚Äô has been used by some to describe the Western Isles, which has disturbed a number of people who have contacted me about this subject.‚ÄúWe have a population that is more elderly and more vulnerable to this virus than most, and so slowing down the spread of the virus has to be our overriding priority.‚ÄúDespite the fact we have a low number of confirmed cases, the true number of infected islanders is likely to be signicantly higher. There is certainly now a need for more testing locally.#We need to keep observing the social distancing guidelines and cannot allow any room for complacency.‚ÄúGiven that we may well be behind the infection curve for the rest of Scotland, there is a good case to be made for a regional approach to lting lockdown restrictions, when that happens. However, this also has to ensure that the islands are not subject to any influx of travellers from other areas where the virus has already peaked.‚ÄùHighlands and Islands Conservative MSP Donald Cameron added: ‚ÄúAny proposal to trial a relaxation of the lockdown rules must have the full support of local residents with the protection of the most vulnerable remaining paramount, as well as ensuring the NHS is not put under any unnecessary strain.‚ÄúHowever, the geography of the islands means they are suitable for a possible trial and Professor Pennington‚Äôs suggestions certainly deserve serious consideration.‚ÄúGiven the fragile nature of the islands# local economy at this time, we need to give our communities every chance of not only getting through this pandemic but also kick-starting a recovery as quickly as possible. This proposal may well help in that endeavour.‚ÄùThe West Highland Free Press online shop is taking no new orders until st May .Sorry for any inconvenience this may cause.

title: agricultural show calendar wiped out
story: The Northern Ireland Shows Associationhas confirmed that  of Northern Ireland‚Äôs local agricultural Shows have cancelled for  due to the continued COVID- pandemic. revealed that Ballymena Show had been cancelled last week and now the Association have rounded up the list of events which have been impacted by the COVID outbreak Other shows that have cancelled include Killyleagh, Ballymoney, Lurgan, Armagh, Newry, Ballymena, Omagh, Castlewellan, Londonderry Limavadycedil Antrim, Clogher Valley and Fermanagh. The Balmoral Show has been postponed to Wednesday th ‚Äì Saturday nd August  while the Saintfield Show has indicated that they hope to run in September with a revised schedule.Ann Orr, Chairman of NISA commented, ‚ÄúThe health and safety of all those who come together to put on the inidual local Shows are our priority. ‚ÄúIt is a dficult situation we all find ourselves in this year and each of the inidual Show Committees have had to look seriously at their position taking into account the months of preparation beforehand, the expense of pre-planning which may not be used - and against that, the loss to the Agri-Food Industry of the valuable contribution the Shows - which cover the six counties of Northern Ireland - makes to the Northern Ireland economy. A major feature of the Agricultural Shows are the  NISA Championships run each year to culminate in the series Championships at the end of the season. Thankfully, our sponsors have all been supportive of the Committees decisions, and we will be back in  stronger than ever. title: council takes lead on dog licence renewals with new text service
story: Mid and East Antrim Borough Council has begun to send Dog Licence reminders directly to residents via mobile phone text alerts in a move that will provide dog owners with the opportunity to renew their licence directly online and that will see cost-savings being made in the process.The first reminder texts were issued to some dog owners whose licences were due for renewal in February.Council has traditionally issued First and Second reminder letters to almost , dog owners across the borough. The new text message reminders could see the administrative costs of issuing reminders slashed by over pound, per year - a saving not to be snfed at.It is anticipated that over the course of   the majority of dog owners will see the benefits of moving towards the new licence reminder texts and will be encouraged to update their account details by logging on to the online dog licencing portal, council.direct.Mayor of Mid and East Antrim Borough Council, Councillor Maureen Morrow, said: ‚ÄúThese new licence reminders, arriving directly to the pet owner‚Äôs mobile phone, will hopefully encourage them to go online and renew their licence straight away.‚ÄúCouncil has been working to embrace innovative methods of communicating with all of our residents and this development sees us fulfilling one of our key targets this year under the Digital Transformation of Council services.‚ÄúI hope that ratepayers embrace these new dog licence reminders and see the benefits it can bring.‚ÄùDog Licence holders are also encouraged to sign up to the Green Dog Walkersscheme which includes a free lead, torch and collar light, and a fresh supply of ‚Äòdoggie bags‚Äô.The GDW initiative, which has been running in Mid and East Antrim since , includes residents taking a pledge to clean up after their pet and encourage others to do the same in order to ‚Äòleave only paw prints‚Äô.For more information on getting or renewing a dog licence go to: www.midandeastantrim.gov.uk dogs

title: reopen cemeteries without delay says nicholl
story: Mid and East Antrim councillor, Alderman Tommy Nicholl MBE, has urged the Northern Ireland Executive to reopen cemeteries to the public ‚Äòwithout delay‚Äô.‚ÄúThere is an urgent and immediate need for the Executive to allow grieving families to visit and tend their loved ones‚Äô final resting places while observing all public health and social distancing guidelines‚Äù, Alderman Nicholl continues.‚ÄúI and other elected representatives have been inundated with calls from people who simply cannot understand why the decision to open cemeteries and graveyards cannot be taken, particularly when parks and green spaces, and even household recycling centres, are rightly accessible.‚ÄúBeing able to visit the grave of someone we have lost is an essential and important part of the grieving process and it is imperative that people are allowed to do that.‚ÄúIt is simply unfathomable for so many of the families who have contacted me that off licences are deemed ‚Äòessential‚Äô while the act of tending a loved one‚Äôs grave is not.‚ÄúI am disappointed that Sinn Fein and the Alliance Party are not supportive of the wishes of all those who continue to grieve during this pandemic.‚ÄúMany of the families I spoke with had been taking their once daily exercise by visiting their loved one‚Äôs final resting place, and they were doing that according to the guidelines on public health protection.‚ÄúThe reopening of cemeteries can be done with the utmost sensitivity and with strict social distancing measures in place, and it needs to happen without delay.‚Äù

title: udr benevolent fund offering support to vulnerable veterans
story: THE UDR Benevolent Fund is calling on any vulnerable former members throughout Northern Ireland, who need help and support during the current COVID- pandemic, to contact them.The registered charity, set up to assist former members, their widows and dependents, is reaching out to vulnerable former members in need to come forwardthey have fallen on hard times or adversity.Brian Kennedy, Secretary of the UDR Benevolent Fund said, ‚ÄúIn a time where even the strongest of iniduals are struggling with the new normality of le, living through the COVID- pandemic, it can be an even more dficult time for those people who are vulnerable and unable to support themselves. ‚ÄúWe want to reiterate the message to those former members that we are here to help.‚ÄúWe know it can be dficult to ask for help there may be a feeling of embarrassment but there shouldn‚Äôt be, and we want to change this. ‚ÄúWe might be able to ease the burden by providing help and support.‚ÄúWhen someone contacts us, they will be referred to a caseworker organisation, whose knowledge and expertise is of the highest level, and who will deal with any issues sensitively and confidentially. ‚ÄúHowever, as part of any grant application process, personal information and supporting documentation will be required. To contact us today, telephone +   or email udrbenfund@outlook.‚ÄùSupport available for those who have proven financial hardship could include financial assistance to help with electrical and heating costs, food vouchers or in some instances, specialised equipment.The charity also offers a respite service however, this service is currently closed due to the Coronavirus COVID- outbreak. The UDR Benevolent Fund spends in the region of poundk per year, providing le changing assistance to those who face dficult times. Applications are dealt with in the strictest confidence at all times.If you are a former member of The Ulster Defence Regiment, a dependent family member oryou know of a former member in need because of sickness, disability, accident, infirmity, poverty or other adversity, contact The UDR Benevolent Fund today on +   or email udrbenfund@outlook.

title: derry meditation teacher helps kids feeling stressed by coronavirus lockdown with online classes
story: Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseHelen McConnell at home yesterday FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsappHelen McConnell at home yesterdayDonna DeeneyTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailChildren struggling with le under lockdown are being thrown a leline by a woman who provides online meditation classes.  The weekly classes by Helen McConnell, aimed at children aged between six and , teach skills on how to cope with missing friends, grandparents, boredom and being confined for long periods at home.Just six months after she launched her meditation classes at North Star Health and Wellbeing Centre in Eglinton and in some schools, Ms McConnell was forced to rethink how best to reach the children taking part.She contacted parents about online classes, which are now proving to be very popular.Normally classes last an hour but these online classes are just half-an-hour long, which we are finding are working well, Ms McConnell said.The classes are for children from primary two to around  or  and I try and tailor them to the issues they are going through right now because of the coronavirus.As the classes are done through Zoom, the parents can participate along with the children, because a relaxed mum is a relaxed child.Ms McConnell explained how they take a dferent theme each week.She added: This week for example we are dealing with sleep, which parents are telling me is a big issue for their children at this particular time.Children are away from their school friends, their home friends, their grandparents, and that is dficult for them, so I teach meditation on how to cope with that.This is a time of great uncertainty, so I teach children to meditate on what they can control and how to deal with what they can#t control.One of their favourites is the #magic carpet ride#, which helps children deal with boredom. Even though we are restricted in where we can go in our everyday le right now, in our imagination we are free to go wherever we like. While delivering her meditation classes online is an unusual way to teach children, Ms McConnell has been pleased at how well the youngsters are adapting.She added: Since I started this I haven#t had one single child who said they didn#t like it, even those who started the class because it was their parents who wanted them to do it. title: ex armagh gaa star marian mcguinnes recovering from coronavirus and cant wait to hug family again
story: Marian McGuinnessÔøΩINPHO Laszlo Geczo FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsappMarian McGuinnessJohn CampbellApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailFormer Armagh ladies football star Marian McGuinness has told how she is beginning the process of stitching her le together again after testing positive for coronavirus at the end of last month.And the Cavan-based physiotherapist is in no doubt as to what her priority will be as she focuses on resuming her career.I have to admit that I have really missed my family of late because of my illness, but now I am just keen to give them all lots of hugs when we#re all in a position to be able to give them out again, she said.Marianis striving to regain her strength and fitness following her spell in isolation in Cavan General Hospital, where she works.Initially I felt sick and insanely tired, recalled Marian. It was just asI had played in an intense match. I thought that it would be best then that I didn#t go to work, and I later developed a high temperature and a small cough.But I do really feel a lot better now. I still have not got my full sense of taste back, but other than that I feel good. I am back at work, thankfully.The morale within Cavan General Hospital is so good that it has actually helped my recovery. Everyone is very positive despite the pressures that they are under. I have taken my inspiration from others who are proving wonderful colleagues in dficult circumstances.Having transferred from the Carrickcruppen club in Armagh to Cavan side Lacken, she is looking forward to resuming playing, having already brought the curtain down on her inter-county career.Marian, who won an Ulster Senior Championship medal with Armagh in , is particularly keen to engage in collective training once again.Yes, it will be a change for me to be training with Lacken, but I am looking forward to it immensely. It will be a new challenge for me, she added. title: if off licences can be open during coronavirus lockdown in ni why cant our cemeteries asks young nurse grieving for mum
story: Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseJulie with her mum Deborah who passed away in  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsappJulie with her mum Deborah who passed away in Claire McNeillyTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA grieving student nurse has told of her devastation at being prohibited from leaving flowers at her beloved mum#s grave.  Julie Dorrian#s mother Deborah passed away in June , aged , after a battle with cancer, and is buried in Carnmoney Cemetery, which has been closed in response to the coronavirus pandemic.Her distress has been exacerbated by the death of her -year-old grandfather from Covid- four days ago.Oliver Dorrian died on Saturday after contracting coronavirus and is due to be buried on Friday, with a maximum of  people permitted to attend the graveside service.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseJulie Dorrian and her grandfather Oliver, who died from Covid- on Saturday FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsappJulie Dorrian and her grandfather Oliver, who died from Covid- on SaturdayJulie, who lives in Carnmoney with her dad David- the late Oliver#s son - told the Belfastthat she is heartbroken at not having been allowed to visit her mum#s grave since the lockdown started. The -year-old also said she definitely doesn#t understand how off-licences can be open and cemeteries closed.I#m very sad I can#t go and visit my mum, she said. When I#m feeling stressed or not feeling good it brings me comfort and peace to be able to go there and spend some time.Read More Coronavirus: Divided parties set to discuss reopening of cemeteries in Northern IrelandIt#s also very important to me to be able to keep the grave tidy and clean and put fresh flowers on it.Julie said both her and her widowed father regularly tend to the grave, adding that her brother Glenn , who lives in Banbridge with his we and children, always makes a special point of going there when he comes to visit them.It#s very rare that I would see anyone  when I go to the cemetery, which makes the decision to shut them even harder to understand, she said.It#s hard enough to live without my mum being around but now I can#t go and be close to her, or even leave flowers.Read More Coronavirus: Find way to open cemeteries in Northern Ireland, pleads woman who lost parents to Covid-Heartbroken Julie also spoke of her sorrow at the recent loss of her grandfather on April .He had been suffering from Alzheimer#s for a long time and was living in a residential home, she said.He contracted the virus and became very, very sick very quickly before he passed away. He was pretty unresponsive. I#ve never seen someone look so ill. It was shocking.For more than a week he was pretty much asleep. At least at the end he was in peace and he wasn#t in pain any more.Oliver#s death represents more heartache for the family at this dficult time because they must say goodbye amid the stringent restrictions that have been imposed as a result of the killer virus.But Julie said that organising his funeral has helped her better understand why a decision to close cemeteries may have been taken, even though she does not agree with it.Read More Coronavirus: It#s cruel to keep graveyards closed, says minister Edwin PootsI can see both sides of the argument because of the position we#re in, she added. We#re having a graveside service on Friday and only  of us are allowed to be there. But I can imagine maybecemeteries were open there would be a risk of more people trying to attend services, but at the end of the day it#s up to people as to how they want to behave.I think politicians need to trust the public more. They should change this policy and allow grieving families to visit their loved ones# final resting places.For me it all comes back to the same question:alcohol shops are open, why aren#t cemeteries She added: I can see both sides but I don#t really understand what harm could be caused by having cemeteries open. Carnmoney is so big and on the very rare occasion that I saw someone  there they were a huge distance away.Julie told how Oliver#s we - and her grandmother - Elizabeth, who was known as Lillian, died suddenly from a heart attack in  and she said she would take great comfort from being able to say a final farewell to her grandad at the graveside this weekend.And she said her family#s proximity to his final place of rest will be all the more poignant given the tragic run up to his recent passing in the early hours of Saturday morning.I think grandad contracted the virus about  days before his death, Julie said.We were just lucky that his room was on the ground floor because that meant that when he was extremely ill me and dad could look in through the window and see him. If he had been upstairs we wouldn#t have been able to. The care assistants were telling him who we were, but I#m not sure he recognised us. story: FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsappBy Staff ReporterApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailTo help readers living in Belfast still get hold of a copy of the Belfastin the current pandemic, we are today launching an additional way to have your paper delivered to your home.We are now working with other publishers to offer a combined title delivery service for those customers who wish to have multiple papers delivered.The Belfasthas been the go-to source of news since the Covid- crisis broke, giving readers essential, accurate and up-to-date information about the pandemic.As communities across Northern Ireland have pulled together to beat the virus, the Belfasthas been there every step of the way, just as we#ve been for the last  years recording the heroic efforts of our frontline healthcare workers, holding politicians rigorously to account, asking the questions that you - our readers - want answered.As more and more people practise social distancing and self-isolating, particularly the elderly and those with pre-existing conditions, a dependable source of news you can trust has never been more important.The Belfastcontinues to offer its own very competitively priced and established service across Northern Ireland and will continue to do so throughout this current situation. If you wish to avail of this service, ring   .However, during this crisis, we are now teaming up with other leading publishers to give readers another way to get a copy of their favourite newspaper.The service is a response to the huge number of requests from readers of the newspapers looking for their paper to be delivered either for themselves, a loved one who is self-isolating, or elderly parents.And signing up to the new service couldn#t be simpler.To get your hands on your favourite Belfastwithout leaving the safety of your home, just visit https:newspaperdelivery.me  The site has all the information you need in an easy-to-understand format and you can be registered for delivery to your home within minutes.BelfastEditor Gail Walker said: Newspapers have never been more A local GP who works at Derry‚Äôs COVID- Centre estimates that because of limited testing the number of people with the virus could be signicantly higher than official reports. In Northern Ireland testing is currently limited to patients who are being admitted to hospital and some health care workers as well as symptomatic nursing home residents. At the time of writing, April , just over , people have been tested for the virus in the North with under , confirmed cases. Whereas more than , tests for Covid- have now been completed in the Republic of Ireland ‚Äì one of the highest testing rates in Europe - resulting in over , confirmed cases. googletag.cmd.push In the south you can phone your GP to be assessed for a testyou are in a priority group and have symptoms. Dr Paul Molloy said limited testing means it is dficult to tell how many people have COVID- and therefore how many have actually died of COVID-. He added that % of cases are mild and don‚Äôt make it as far as GPs or the hospital and % probably do with % severely affected. googletag.cmd.push Out of the % that make it to the COVID Centre probably  % of them are at present sent home again without being tested as only those admitted are tested, he said. That means that doctors are potentially only testing a very small proportion of those actually affected. He did caveat the statement by saying he is a GP and not a statistician or an epidemiologist. ‚ÄúThe dficulty is that many people in the community have other illnesses like COPD, heart disease etc,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúIt is very possible thatthese people acquired COVID- it would be too much for them to cope with and they‚Äôd die at home. This would be similar to people dying of influenza. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll not be recorded on their death certicate but it may have been the final illness that just was too much to cope with and been the precipitating factor for death. If these people die at home from COVID- it will be unknown as at present we are only testing those who are admitted to hospital. ‚ÄúAll the people who are in the community with a flu do not knowit is coronavirus or another virus. ‚ÄúWe have no idea therefore of the real numbers of patients affected or even the real number of deaths.‚Äù UNDER-REPORTING While this isn‚Äôt important in managing the illness, he says, it does become important when a discussion takes place about moving out of the current lockdown. ‚ÄúWe know that about % of the population have to be infected before we develop herd immunity. ‚ÄúThis was the original path the government set out on. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also important that when restrictions are lted we can employ similar means to the countries who have been most successful in controlling this. ‚ÄúThat is quickly identying pockets of virus in the community, isolating those pockets, tracing and testing any contacts and avoiding indiscriminate spread. ‚ÄúThere are many, many people, % of those with COVID  out there who will only get mild symptoms. The Western Trust has confirmed that  staff members remain absent from work due to the coronavirus. Those workers are based in the Northern sector which takes in Derry, Strabane and Limavady. It comes after the Derry News revealed earlier this month that  workers were off across the Trust area because of COVID- - the illness that can affect your lungs and airways which is caused by coronavirus. Of those employees,  worked at Altnagelvin Hospital. There was a relatively even split between the numbers self-isolating due to symptoms of their own and those isolating because family members had symptoms. googletag.cmd.push Testing has been ramped up in dferent parts of NI, including Derry where a facility has just opened at City of Derry Rugby Club, to ensure that health and social care staff are kept safe. It is also hoped that testing will allow staff who are following government guidelines by isolating - but are not actually sick - toto work so they can assist during the first wave of coronavirus cases. However, according to the latest figures available  staff members are still absent. In a statement to the Derry News on Friday, a spokesperson for the Western Trust confirmed: ‚ÄúWhilst a number of staff have ed to work following a period of absence some staff have commenced new episodes of absence related to coronavirus. googletag.cmd.push ‚ÄúThe total number of staff absent as at th April is . Since the introduction of testing on th March  and up to th April  a total of  Northern Sector staff have been tested ‚Äì this covers both hospital and community staff.‚Äù Approximately , people responded to a workforce appeal by the Trust to allow it to cope with an increased demand on services in light of the coronavirus pandemic. That included retired doctors and student nurses who have joined the frontline. A quarter of those applicants have commenced work in a range of roles. A spokesperson explained. ‚ÄúThe Trust recently launched a workforce appeal for staff and have appointed  staff to date. ‚ÄúThe recruitment team is continuing to process a large number of applications.‚Äù Northern Ireland is nearing the end of what was described as the first wave of cases which was expected to peak between April -. Under this ‚Äòreasonable worst case scenario‚Äô, the projected number of cumulative COVID- deaths in Northern Ireland over  weeks of the epidemic would be ,. The latest Public Health Agencybulletin, as of April , reports  deaths. It is believed that this peak may be less severe than first anticipated but last Thursday saw the highest daily rise with  COVID related deaths in NI hospitals. That total was matched on Friday and a further  people tested positive, a development Health Minister Robin Swann described was a ‚Äòwake up call‚Äô as he warned against complacency. On Saturday a further  deaths were registered and one more person was added to the overall death toll on Sunday. TESTING Almost , people have been tested for COVID- in Northern Ireland - over , of them health care workers. The current target is set at over , tests per day with a view to scaling up over time and expanding priority groups. The test centre at City of Derry Rugby Club will assist with that upscaling. Criticism has been levelled at the government for limited testing in the community and contact tracing as that will be crucial when it comes to estimating population immunity and designing an exit strategy to move out of the current lockdown. Speaking last week Minister of Health Robin Swann said: ‚ÄúTesting of health care workers has been a key priority of mine and I am glad that in recent weeks we have tested over , of our frontline staff. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs important for them, and it‚Äôs also important for the people they support such as the residents in our care homes.‚Äù He continued: ‚ÄùAn expert working group has also been established to lead on the expansion of testing across all our laboratory services, both within Health and Social Care facilities, and also to consider options for the utilisation of other testing facilities including within the commercial sector. ‚ÄúThere is a NI Testing Strategy that has already been shared with the Executive and the Health Committee. The government has published an extensive list of essential workers along with guidance on how to improve workplace safety during the current coronavirus crisis. Yesterday, the Department for the Economy released a guide setting out principles and practical steps for employers and employees to keep themselves and their workplaces safe. It also highlights the steps to be followedemployers and employees are concerned about safety. In Derry a number of businesses remain operational at present offering delivery, collection and online services. Other independent businesses in the city are selling ‚Äòno expiry date‚Äô vouchers and fitness centres are streaming workouts via Zoom. googletag.cmd.push The workplace safety guidance published this week is accompanied by a list of priority business sectors. The sectors list aims to clary what constitutes a priority sector at this time and to support companies to continue their business operationsthey can work within social distancing guidelines. Sectors include manufacturing which takes in food and drink, businesses making PPE garments, newspaper printers, manufacturers of chemicals, pharmaceuticals, computer electronic components, cyber products and ‚Äòproducts critical to local, national global supply chains that are responding to the COVID- crisis.‚Äô Other sectors are mining and quarrying, distribution, financial and insurance, agriculture, forestry and fishery and construction - when it relates to emergency services and emergency repairs to homes. googletag.cmd.push Meanwhile, service industries include transport, food delivery and takeaway, services providing food and drink to those imprisoned or homeless, print and broadcast media, postal service, veterinary activities, dentistry, funeral directors and laundrettes. A cinema, theatre or concert Hall can broadcast a performance to people outside the premises over the internet, or on radio or televisionEconomy Minister Diane Dodds published the guidance on making workplaces safer and the list of priority sectors which were drawn up by the Engagement Forum. The Forum was set up by the Minister to advise the Executive on the list of priority businesses sectors referred to in the Health Protection Regulations. It was also asked to advise on measures required to protect the safety of all workers. The forum is chaired by the Labour Relations Agencyand consists of representatives from business organisations, trade unions, local councils, government, the Health and Safety Executive NI, Public Health Agency and Food Standards Agency. It drew up a list of priority business sectors and developed guidance on safe working practices during the current COVID- crisis. The Minister presented these to the Executive on Monday, which agreed to publish both papers.
