If a company can work within the social distancing guidelines then it should do so. ‚ÄúThe safety guidance will have practical application in the workplace. ‚ÄúAlong with the accompanying guidance on safe working practices, the list is there to protect everyone in the workplace, to ensure our essential supply chains remain solid and to help Northern Ireland be ready to rebuild its economy when this crisis has passed.‚Äù She went on to say that the aim of the priority sectors list, which is fully supported by both business and union representatives on the Forum, is to clary what constitutes a priority sector at this time, and to support Northern Ireland companies to continue their business operations and protect the incomes of their workforces. The National Union of Studentshas called for the introduction of a hardship fund and an option for students to retake or be reimbursed for the academic year after research showed concern for their future job prospects. The call comes after the results of the NUS Coronavirus and Students Survey , which involved almost , students across all regions, age ranges and learning experiences in the UK. Covid- has left students fearful for their futures, with % indicating concern over the virus impact on the wider economy, while % expressed concern about future job prospects. % of working students said they may require extra financial support as that income drops, but just % indicated they were at critical risk of being unable to access their education. googletag.cmd.push Almost three-quarters were worried about the risk to their final qualications, while % were worried about the impact of the pandemic on their employability. In response to the surveys findings, the NUS has called on the government to provide a pound million national hardship fund and an economic package for those who complete their qualications during the pandemic. The union has also pressed for the option for every student to redo the year at no further cost, while receiving full maintenance support, or for a reimbursement for the academic year. NUS National President,Zamzam Ibrahim, said the need for a safety net was urgent. googletag.cmd.push Coronavirus has hit thousands of students in the pocket and severely affected the quality of their learning, he said. The majority are paying extortionate fees for their education and are treated as consumers but are left out in the cold when the product cannot be delivered as described. Face-to-face teaching and assessments have had to be hurriedly moved online, and placement and other practical activity has had to be cancelled. Students have lacked access to key resources, such as libraries and spaces, disabled students have been left unsupported, and students and staff have been struggling with other demands on their finances, welfare and wider lives as lockdown restrictions are enforced. Students are being forgotten during the Covid- pandemic. We are the future workforce that will have to help to rebuild our economy over the coming years. The NUS is a confederation of over  student unions across the UK and works with more than % of all higher and further education students. Le has slowed in recent weeks. We are now entering the th day of lockdown with strict regulations in place to curb the spread of Covid-. The current situation is set to last until at least May  and as many seek comfort from the virus‚Äô threat, they are turning their attention towards happier days. Re-runs of old TV programmes are filling the airwaves. The GAA has made  All-Ireland finals available to watch online. News archives are being pored over for hidden gems. Nostalgia is king at the moment, but Maghera psychologist Sarah Connell is not surprised by the phenomenon. googletag.cmd.push ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a really comforting emotion,‚Äù says the owner of Minding Me Psychologists. ‚ÄúIt brings back times when we‚Äôve been accepted and loved, and it provides some badly needed relief in these times of uncertainty. ‚ÄúPeople are generally frightened by change, because we don‚Äôt always feel like we‚Äôre in control of things. Having that sense of being in control is really important for our well-being. ‚ÄúWe can retreat to the past and think of when times were good, and we felt like we were in more control of things. I think that really helps us to be more stabilised and feel better about things. googletag.cmd.push ‚ÄúI think sometimes we can use it as a wee bit of an escape as well. It can take us out of the situation we are in that, for some people, is really challenging.‚Äù Although nostalgia is widely regarded as a positive emotion, this was not always the case and early research into the area deemed it to be a psychological problem. The term was coined by Swiss doctor Johannes Hoffer in , who deemed it a ‚Äòneurological disease of essentially demonic cause‚Äô after studying Swiss mercenaries stationed abroad. It arose from the Greek terms nostos ‚Äì meaning a yearning tohome ‚Äì and algos ‚Äì its associated pain. Hoffer also concluded that the condition may have been caused by incessant cowbells in the Alps causing damage to the soldiers‚Äô ears and brain cells. Even throughout the th and th centuries, it carried the stigma of ‚Äòimmigrant psychosis‚Äô, a form of ‚Äòmelancholia‚Äô and a ‚Äòmentally regressive compulsive disorder‚Äô. Sarah describes the concept as ‚Äòbittersweet‚Äô and refers to it as a ‚Äòdouble-edged sword‚Äô. ‚ÄúBecause it triggered dissatisfaction and lots of negative emotions like stress, fear and loss, it was interpreted as something you don‚Äôt want to have,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt really is bittersweet. It‚Äôs sweet because we‚Äôre remembering the good times, all the things that were good in the past, but it‚Äôs bitter because we know we can never regain that experience. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs gone forever. Time is irreversible and there‚Äôs something really sad about that. ‚ÄúThe song ‚ÄòDays of Our Lives‚Äô by Queen has the lines: ‚ÄòCan‚Äôt turn back the clock, can‚Äôt turn back time, ain‚Äôt that a shame‚Äô and I think that really summarises it well. ‚ÄúAlthough it‚Äôs a lovely thing to think back, we can‚Äôt turn back the time. It‚Äôs really positive in one way but there‚Äôs a downside to it as well.‚Äù Nostalgia is often triggered by activities that people enjoy, such as music or sport, and Sarah says this is especially the case during a time of psychological distancing. ‚ÄúIt can really help counteract feelings of loneliness,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a huge link because those [music and sport] are things we love. If we think back to times when you played a good match, or went to an enjoyable concert, those are happy memories. ‚ÄúNostalgic thoughts unite us with people again in our minds. It increases the perception of social support and reminds us of a time when we were with people, doing things and enjoying them.‚Äù A rise in nostalgia can often be a result of coming face-to-face with your own mortality and as the death toll in Northern Ireland reaches , people are increasingly worried. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs giving them that sense that you actually can die,‚Äù says Sarah. ‚ÄúSome people are quite concerned about it, but others probably still feel an element of ‚Äòthat‚Äôs not going to happen to me‚Äô. ‚ÄúOne thing many are most concerned about is the economic effect that it‚Äôs having. They‚Äôre concerned about job loss ‚Äì a lot of people have been furloughed. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôll be wonderingtheir job will continue after this period and what will happen in terms of paying bills and mortgages. The fear that we are going to go into recession is causing worries. Through talking to clients, Sarah has heard many people talk about the unexpected positive aspects that have arisen from the effects of the lockdown. She says: ‚ÄúI am hearing a lot of people really focusing on the positives, which is great. They are loving having more precious time to spend with their families and their children. ‚ÄúLittle things like the slower pace of le ‚Äì you can hear the birds singing more in the mornings. It‚Äôs giving time for people to reflect and re-evaluate their lives. Although the psychological distancing that we are currently having to enforce increases feelings of isolation and loneliness, people are adapting. Sarah says: ‚ÄúPeople are finding ways of coping with it by trying to find a bit of regularity in their lives - doing things like exercise every day and keeping some kind of structure to their day. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve gone from being able to do whatever we want to having massive restrictions on us. ‚ÄúNone of us like being told what to do or being held back from living our lives how we want to live them. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre having to draw on our willpower to focus and do the things that are right for ourselves and for everyone.‚Äù If nostalgia can act as a buffer against the fear and frustration caused by Covid-, then open that GAA archive, put on the old TV re-runs and wallow in reminiscent therapy. Derry authorJudeMorrow should be in America right now launchinghis debut book about being an autistic dad, insteadhe is in Derry working on the frontline as a social worker with the elderly.Although he loves his day job, you can forgive thefather of one for feeling disappointed.His book tour was the stuff of dreams, with a guest lecture at Stanford University and a book sign at Barnes and Noble in San Mateo, Calornia, and had been months in the planning.You only get one debut book release and thats it, he says. Judes story is all the more remarkable given that his book Why Does Daddy Always Look So Sad was first self published just last May.By October his searingly honest account of being autistic and being a father had been snapped up by Beyond Words the same American company that published worldwide best selling self help book The Secret.Judesays he wrote thebookfor his son Ethan, now , to show autstic peoples livescan be every bit as happy and fulfilled as those not on the spectrum. The title of the book came from a question Ethan, who is not autistic, askedJudesmum when he was just three.Judestarted writing the book to record his childhood and journey into fatherhood, after realising that most of the books on autism focused on children, not parents. googletag.cmd.push It was a bit of a bucket list thing, to have a book published before I was , he says.  I wanted to make a record of my early le and Ethans early le.Im proudly autistic now but that wasnt always the case.I used to try and hide it.After sending it off to a string of literary agents with no successJudepublished it himself and it went on to earn a stringof five star reviews on Amazon and attractedthe attention of one of the worlds leading consultants on autism, Maisie Soetantyo.Why Does Daddy Always Look so Sad  also caught the eye of an American literary agent who took it to Beyond Words Publishing.Impressed byJudes warts and all story which detailed his childhood struggles, through to adaptingto becoming a parent they agreed to launch the book in the US with a speaking tour.Beyond Words Publishing get submissions from all over the world but they only publish about  books a year so for them to publish my book is just unbelievable, saysJude. googletag.cmd.push I never in my widest dreams thought this was going to happen.The publishers said the book resonates with people because its not about swimming the channel or climbing Everest, Im just a normal, relatable person.Im remarkably unremarkable but they thought it was important to get my story out there.For the past eight monthsJudehas been working closely with his publisher to plan the promotion of his book.They are eight hours behind me, so I wouldbe finishing work atpm and they would just be starting, he explains.But with the outbreak of the coronavirus all the carefully laid plans have had to be scrapped.Its in the lap of the gods, but I just dont want it to vanish without a trace, says Jude.I want to out it in frontof as many people as possible. Growing up dferentJude, who grew up in the Bogside before moving to the Waterside, says he knew from a young age that he was dferent.I have never felt not dferent, he says.ObviouslyI have always been autistic, and I always would have been aware too that other children would be out playing games or playing in the street and I spent most of my time alone.Juderecalls spending hours lining up his toy cars on the window sill of his childhood home in Gartan Square.By a stroke of luck the flat recently came up for sale and Locate Estate Agents agreed to let him come and have a look around.That was magic, saysJude.The atmosphere was still the same.I could just imagine my mammy and my daddy there and my wee sister Emily tottering aboutI rang up Locate because Im a chancer and said Ive written this book and its out all over the world and a lot of happened there.Growing up Jude went to the Model School Derry, Oakgrove and St Columbs College.I had a lot of help and support and at the time I was resentful of it, but I look back more fondlyat it now, he saysThere were no autism support groups in the city at that time, so when Jude was a teenager he joined cross community youth group Reach Across.His lazer focus and love of order were put to good use helping to organise activities and grant applications and at  he was invited back to the group as a leader.This led him on to a Social Work degree at Ulster University, Magee.The boy who has social dficulty ended up being a social worker, he smiles. Becoming a dadJudesaid he used to perceive autism as something that he had grown out of.He had a successful job as a social worker and was able to navigate le well. But becomingadad at the age of  threw his carefullyordered world into disarray.Instead of cherishing and celebrating this wee baby I was more preoccupied with wheres my sense of control , he admits.When Ethan was three he asked his granny the heart wrenching question why does daddy always look so sad , which was to become the title of the book.He was able to pick up that I wasnt happy or that I found things dficult, Jude explains.And he still knows when Im not happy.Hes  now and he knows that I like things done a certain way.I have a lot of buttons and he has lots of wee fingers to press them with, he laughs.So was Ethans question the catalyst that turned Jude into the perfect father No, that would be far too easy, he sighs.It wasnt a lightbulb moment.Embracing being autistic and fatherhood was a gradual process that has continued after the publication of the book.I had to give in and accept I was autistic.I would have said i have autism but I have become more educated and listened to autism voices and they would say they are autstic, not that they have autism.Its not a handbag or an accessory that you have.Its an intrinsic piece of someone.I used to think in my own head I have a condition, but its the way I am.Its not something fatal or that needs treatment.Judes view of autism has come full circle and he now regards it as a blessing.To me its an advantage and to a lot of autistic people its an advantage.Autistic people are the most passionate and driven iniduals.If it wasnt for autstic people there would be no fire, no wheel, no electricity, no music, no arts, nothing!   Reaching outSince publishing the book last yearJudehas given a series of talks and book signings which have given the -year-old social worker the chance to reach out to autistic children.I love meeting autistic kids.They are like me and I am like them.Im not in the business of giving parenting advice and when I give a talk to parents its always the kids who ask the questions.Theres a misconception that autistic kids dont know they are dferent.I want to tell them that things will be grand.He has also been contacted by people from around the world who have been touched by his story and he has encouraged anyone with questions to get in touch with him online.I reach out to people all the time and I have a black belt in responding, saysJude.Why Does Daddy Always Look so Sad  is available on Amazon in both paperback and ebook.For more information seewww.judemorrowor theJudeMorrowAuthor page on Facebook. One of Derrys most popular food outlets has reopened for takeaways today, much to the delight of its customers. Pyke n Pommes has implemented a number of practices to keepboth staff and customers safe at its branch on Derrys Quay.The chains Strand Road restaurant closed its doors on March  and trialled a delivery service.But less than a week later the decision was taken to close both therestaurant and the pod ontheriver front.However, almost a month on, owner Kevin Pyke has decided to reopen the branch on the Quay for takeaway and collectiononly, with their outside terrace and double decker bus seating areas to remain closed.In a Facebook Live video Mr Pyke said the businesswas reopeningfrom Wednesdays through to Sundays and would be taking a number of measures to ensure the safety of both staff and customers.All staff will be wearing gloves and regularly sanitising their work space and markerswill be in place to help people queue two metres apart.We made the decision, it wasnt the easiest decision, but we decided to reopen that we were going to try opening up down the river front for a few days in the week, he said.In the video Mr Pyke explained customers can order and pay over the phone, and leave their car registration so the food can be delivered to their vehicle.Customers can also order at the pod where they will have the option to pay contactlessly and a queue system that allows for social distancing will be in place.This is a new thing for us, we are just trying this to see it works. I think Derry deserves a Legenderry burger, said Mr Pyke.He added it wasimportant people did not congregate around the premises and suggested customers could take a short walk down the Quay while their food was being prepared.Pyke n Pommes at the riverfront will be open for food orders on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Sundays from pm-pm and on Fridays and Saturdays from pm to pm.To place an order telephone  or.-- googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. One of Derrys most popular food outlets has reopened for takeaways today, much to the delight of its customers. Pyke n Pommes has implemented a number of practices to keepboth staff and customers safe at its branch on Derrys Quay.The chains Strand Road restaurant closed its doors on March  and trialled a delivery service.But less than a week later the decision was taken to close both therestaurant and the pod ontheriver front.However, almost a month on, owner Kevin Pyke has decided to reopen the branch on the Quay for takeaway and collectiononly, with their outside terrace and double decker bus seating areas to remain closed.In a Facebook Live video Mr Pyke said the businesswas reopeningfrom Wednesdays through to Sundays and would be taking a number of measures to ensure the safety of both staff and customers.All staff will be wearing gloves and regularly sanitising their work space and markerswill be in place to help people queue two metres apart.We made the decision, it wasnt the easiest decision, but we decided to reopen that we were going to try opening up down the river front for a few days in the week, he said.In the video Mr Pyke explained customers can order and pay over the phone, and leave their car registration so the food can be delivered to their vehicle.Customers can also order at the pod where they will have the option to pay contactlessly and a queue system that allows for social distancing will be in place.This is a new thing for us, we are just trying this to see it works. I think Derry deserves a Legenderry burger, said Mr Pyke.He added it wasimportant people did not congregate around the premises and suggested customers could take a short walk down the Quay while their food was being prepared.Pyke n Pommes at the riverfront will be open for food orders on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Sundays from pm-pm and on Fridays and Saturdays from pm to pm.To place an order telephone  or.-- googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Jimmy McGilligan whofound his purpose in rural India.Jimmy and we Janak on their wedding day.Reporter: Liam Tunney::  Apr   addthis, Conferred an OBE for his work alongside we Janak in developing the Barli Development Institute for Rural Women in Indore, Liam Tunney tells the remarkable and tragic story of the Garvagh-born drainage contractor who found his purpose in rural India. There are , miles between Garvagh and the city of Chandigarh in the Indore district of Madhya Pradesh in India, but for Jimmy McGilligan, distance was trivial. Jimmy‚Äôs acceptance of the Baha‚Äôi faith in  marked the beginning of an extraordinary journey that would culminate in a visit to Windsor Castle to receive an OBE in . A former boy scout, who helped his father on the farm, Jimmy received pound compensation after losing a toe in an agricultural accident aged just . He used the money wisely, buying a digger and beginning to build up his business from scratch, while also maintaining an amateur radio station from his home between  and . googletag.cmd.push Gradually, he become frustrated with the wastage he encountered through his profession, often expressing disappointment at seeing milk dumped into the sea and the beef farming surplus.  ‚ÄúHe was very passionate about the environment,‚Äù says we Janak, who still lives in the couple‚Äôs home, a self-sustaining farm in a mountainous region of central India. ‚ÄúHe used to lead walks as part of the Ulster Rambling Club and he also was very proud to have a radio license and built his own radio station. ‚ÄúHe was in the Orange Order - they used to call him the first Orange man who accepted Baha‚Äôi faith!‚Äù googletag.cmd.push After volunteering in a Baha‚Äôi centre in Haa, it was felt that Jimmy‚Äôs skills could be put to work where and he was invited to volunteer in Madhya Pradesh, India. It was there that a chance encounter brought him into contact with his future we. ‚ÄúJimmy was asked to reclaim  acres of land for a residential school for rural boys near Gwalior. It had marshy lands and it needed his skills,‚Äù says Janak. ‚ÄúI was on my way from Delhi to Indore and I had no vehicle of my own. I had been working for three years, starting an institute for rural girls from a piece of barren land. ‚ÄúThe Australian High Commission donated a jeep and I had a driver who wanted to see this school that was on our way to Indore. ‚ÄúWe stopped there for a while and I told the principal of the school that I only had a short while, but he said he had a volunteer that wanted to see my institute. ‚ÄúI looked at my watch and told him I only had  minutes, butyour volunteer wants to come, we can take him with us. ‚ÄúThat volunteer was Jimmy. Twenty-five minutes later, he was in our jeep and we brought him home.‚Äù SPACE AT A PREMIUM  If Jimmy was expecting the comforts of his County Derry home, he was in for a rude awakening as, with the institute in its infancy, accommodation was at a premium. ‚ÄúI had no space at that time,‚Äù says Janak. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt give him an apartment or a room, but there was a small room where we used to keep the girls‚Äô mattresses during the day. ‚ÄúWhen the  or so mattresses were taken out, Jimmy could sleep ‚Äì and it was not a soft bed! ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know anything about the people in Northern Ireland. There was no toilet, he had to walk to the outhouse. There was no flushing system and you had to pour a can of water in.‚Äù Jimmy‚Äôs work ethic was insatiable. He set about preparing six acres of land, armed with little more than a Swiss Army kne from his keen interest in mountaineering. The Garvagh man was more used to working with heavy machinery, but after navigating the more primitive pick and spade and settling into his work, he had a suggestion for Janak. ‚ÄúWe had three visitors arrive to see the institute one day,‚Äù she smiles. ‚ÄúJimmy was talking to them and said it was such important work that he could spend all his le there. This was his proposal. ‚ÄúI said he was welcome, but his visa was ending soon. An elderly Baha‚Äôi man, who was sitting close by and who was very fatherly to us, then spoke. ‚ÄúHe looked at me and he told Jimmy: This is your visa. The three girls started talking to me and they were encouraging me to talk to him about this.‚Äù The couple agreedJimmy was granted a visa to remain in India, they would discuss getting married and they travelled together to Delhi to meet the authorities. LUCK  With the country‚Äôs laws permitting only foreign women to remain in India after marrying Indian men, and not the other way around, Jimmy and Janak needed a stroke of luck. ‚ÄúWhen they found out I was the only person in central India working in a programme with funding from the Ministry of Science and Technology, he said they couldn‚Äôt afford to let me go. ‚ÄúThey made an exception ‚Äì he said to go and get married and they would sort out the visa.‚Äù Now engaged, the couple headed straight for Janak‚Äôs family home in Chandigarh. With no phones or internet, the news had to be delivered in person. ‚ÄúWe had no other way of communicating,‚Äù laughs Janak. ‚ÄúWe just arrived home on an ordinary bus at midnight. My mother opened the door to us and was shocked, but very happy with the news. ‚ÄúShe was always complaining I was not going to get married. My four brothers and sisters were married with children and I always said I would never get married - Jimmy used to say that too. ‚ÄúIt was the middle of the night, so she ran to where my father was sleeping, pulled back the blanket and said: ‚ÄòGet up, your daughter is here with this boy and she wants to get married!‚Äô. ‚ÄúMy father just asked Jimmy one question. He askedJimmy was a Baha‚Äôi and when Jimmy said he was, my father said: ‚ÄòGod bless you, only a Baha‚Äôi could keep my daughter happy.‚Äù The pair exchanged rings the next evening and on November , , less than a month after first meeting, Jimmy and Janak were married.  After a brief honeymoon in the mountains, they ed to work at the institute, and a few months later, with Jimmy now installed as manager, the couple visited his home country. ‚ÄúEveryone was constantly talking about the weather,‚Äù recalls Janak. ‚ÄúThey kept telling me I had brought Indian weather, no one was asking about my mother or father. In India, we ask about everything. ‚ÄúI got into that rhythm eventually. The next morning my father in law asked me how I was doing, so I said it was a lovely day.‚Äù Janak fell in love with Northern Ireland, but as Baha‚Äôi pioneers, both her and Jimmy ed to their responsibilities at the Barli Institute, where the Garvagh man was adored by the students. ‚ÄúJimmy picked up all the Hindi in female speech because he learned it from the girls,‚Äù says Janak. ‚ÄúThese girls came from an area where they were treated as ‚Äòuntouchables‚Äô, almost equal to slaves in the past. ‚ÄúJimmy would work with them - not like a boss, but as a father or elderly brother. He was very kind to the girls.‚Äù Janak suffered a health scare in  when she was diagnosed with breast cancer, and Jimmy, who had seen his mother die from the same disease, was deeply worried. After surgery, Janak thankfully made a full recovery and the couple added celebration to relief when Jimmy received acclaim for his years of sterling work in India.  ‚ÄúIn , the lady from British Deputy High Commission appointed him as a warden of British citizens in Indore and she nominated his name for OBE,‚Äù beams Janak. ‚ÄúHe was conferred OBE in  after I had recovered from cancer. We both travelled and I had the privilege of going with him to Windsor Castle to receive the award. ‚ÄúIt brought a lot of joy to all of our families and friends and was a huge recognition for him. After my recovery and this award, we made the decision to hand the institute over to our successors.‚Äù Janak and Jimmy set about making plans to retire and began training up another couple to take on the institute, but they were far from idle. The couple built a beautul house on a piece of farmland in Sanawadiya. The people of the village were living in darkness, so Jimmy built a solar and wind power station on site for them. Retirement was planned for April , , but tragedy struck just days before they were due to hand the institute over. Janak and Jimmy were travelling in a taxi when it was involved in a car accident on April  and Jimmy succumbed to fatal internal injuries on April . While admitting to feeling ‚Äòcompletely lost‚Äô without Jimmy, Janak is determined to honour his memory at their home. ‚ÄúI still run the solar and wind power station and call it the Jimmy McGilligan Centre for Sustainable Development. We train people here free of charge in sustainable technology. ‚ÄúIt was a small, rocky place but now there are maybe  trees and we grow everything that we eat here. ‚ÄúThere is a Baha‚Äôi saying that suits Jimmy and I well ‚Äì humanity is a bird with two wings. The bird can only fly when both wings support each other. Jimmy and I were a really good bird.‚Äù Jimmy McGilligan would have celebrated his thbirthday last week, a man from humble beginnings whose dedication and integrity ensured he soared to a great height. From a meeting in Sam ODonnells house in Dernaflaw, the club has exploded into what it is today. Terence McMacken played in the first ever game, has been player of the year and now holds the position of club secretary. He spoke to Michael McMullan... Last September, a bumper attendance flocked to a packed Roe Park Hotel in Limavady to mark  years of Dungiven Celtic. A celebration of a story that evolved from early jottings in the late s, before the club stretched its wings to fly to the top of intermediate football by the early noughties. The thriving youth scene means Dungiven Celtic is here to stay. Its all thanks to the people involved, according to club stalwart and current secretary Terence McMacken, as he carries the baton held by his late father John Joe. googletag.cmd.push All-time leading goalscorer Seamus Harkin is now the club chairman. Every week, the club fields seven -a-side teams, now has added a snowballing girls soccer string to its bow - under the leadership of James Doran - and last year hosted almost  kids at their annual summer camp. Currently, like every sporting venue around the globe, their Ballyguddin home lies dormant. The lock-down has left the sporting landscape a deserted one. For Dungiven Celtic, its a pit stop on a race that began in June . ‚ÄúBack then, there was a lot of summer soccer played,‚ÄùMcMacken outlines. ‚ÄúWe played summer cups and people who were enthusiastic about the game got involved. Every townland would have had a team.‚Äù googletag.cmd.push Feeny FC were in vogue, playing their games where Banaghers Fr McNally Park is now situated. Many players from the Dungiven area would have turned out for them. They had the makings of a decent side, but soon dissolved. Almost immediately, Dernaflaw Rovers sprung up, playing mainly in cup competitions before the realisation dawned of a hunger for more action in a more regular and organised format. There was the inkling to join the Derry and District Sunday morning leaguefor the start of the   season. ‚ÄúA meeting was called in Sam ODonnells house and that is how it started.‚Äù McMacken adds. ‚ÄúSam had played on the Feeny team at the time.‚Äù And there it was, Dungiven Celtic was founded. *** With the clubs green and white hooped jerseys on order from Seamus Dorans sports shop in Dungiven, the club kicked off their existence in ODonnells red and white striped kit. By the end of that season, the club were in the green, white and black colours associated with the club to this very day. It all began with a trip to the Brandywell on Sunday, August ,  for the clubs first game, against Moville who were one of the Donegal teams in the DD league. Vinny Hargan scored a hat-trick in the - win. Between the posts was Dungiven and Derry Gaelic goalkeeper John Sommers. Also on the team were stalwarts Gerard Kelly and Terence McMacken. ‚ÄúWe didnt really know what to expect,‚Äù McMacken recalls. ‚ÄúWe had played in friendlies at the time, there was no real social media, so we thought this would be a good Moville team wed be playing against. ‚ÄúWe played very well. We may have been a bit inconsistent, but we had a lot of good footballers around here and were better than we gave ourselves credit for.‚Äù By the end of , the club won their first trophy when they ed victorious from the Brandywell with the McKinney Cup thanks to two goals from Hugh Doherty. ‚ÄúWe beat Brandywell Harpsin the final and they were the top team in the city at the time, so that was a big win,‚Äù McMacken adds. Saturday football then began, when the club entered a team into the North West senior league, with many of the players mixing it with a DD game on a Sunday, as well as playing Gaelic games. At the age of , Gerry McElhinney came to play for Dungiven Celtic. He would be waiting at Park bridge every Saturday where he would be collected for a game. By , he was an all-star Gaelic footballer with Derry and was playing on loan from Celtic at Finn Harps. ‚ÄúFrom Dungiven Celtic, Gerry moved to Distillery and was playing very well for them before being snapped up by Bolton Wanderers,‚Äù recalls McMacken. ‚ÄúI can alsoremember Anthony Tohillplaying for Park out at Ballyguddin on the Saturday before he went on trial at Manchester United.‚Äù By the end of the s, there was talk of a new Northern Ireland Intermediate league on the horizon. ‚ÄúIt was for clubs who were quite ambitious,‚Äù McMacken begins. ‚ÄúThe Irish league, at a higher level, was a closed shop. There were local clubs, who wanted to play at a higher level, but had no outlet. Some people in the club said well not and others wanted to give it a go and see where it goes.‚Äù It was the beginning of the climb. *** In August , Jack Doherty was Dungivens goalscorer in a - defeat to Cookstown United at the Curragh Road in the intermediate league cup. The next leg of the journey began. In the team was Scot Dougie Wood, who had spells with Sunderland and Raith Rovers, before moving to Ireland, where he won both league and cup honours with Derry City. ‚ÄúHe came to us in his mid-s and was Dungiven Celtics player manager until he was around ,‚Äù McMacken states. The clubs longest serving manager Jim McGroarty then came on board. A Lettershandoney man, he played with Finn Harps before going over the water to Stoke City. After ato Ireland, he had a spell with Sligo Rovers before going back to the Harps. ‚ÄúWhen we won our first intermediate trophy , we beat Derry City in the final of the North West Challenge Cup,‚Äù McMacken adds. ‚ÄúDougie had stepped down as manager, Jim was back playing for Sligo on a Sunday, so he took over as manager.‚Äù Another constant during that era was Martin Hazlett, who sadly passed away last year. Terence McMackens diligent record keeping charts Hazletts  appearances for the club. He played in the clubs first game at intermediate level, was player of the year in the  season and picked up the award for the sixth time, some  years later.  Martin Hazlett celebrates cup glory for Dungiven Was he the clubs greatest player  ‚ÄúThere is no doubt about it, he was a wonderful player,‚Äù came McMackens prompt reply. ‚ÄúHe always came to play a game properly prepared and he was always in good shape. He took his football seriously and I always thought he couldve played where ‚Äì a higher level.‚Äù Hazlett was very much a home bird and lived beside the pitch, playing right up until the clubs golden era at the late s and was the glue to pull the team together until the younger crop game along. ‚ÄúWe had always had decent teams, but theleague was of a very high standard. Quite a number of the teams, they had people getting paid and were professional teams. We were holding our own, but were never good enough to win it.‚Äù In the Irish Cup, the club had two impressive runs during the s. They reached the sixth round in the   season, before going down to Loughgall. Along the way, they defeated local rivals Limavady United. The following season, they took on Irish League champions Crusaders at Seaview, going down - after giving a good account of themselves. It helped keep the momentum going and after knocking on the door for a few years, Intermediate league success was to follow. *** In the beginning, Dungiven Celtic played their games between the county school, a pitch on the Hass Road and on the Garvagh Road, where Paacuteirc na nOacuteg Gaelic pitch is now situated. ‚ÄúThe council bought a field up at the Curragh Road and it has been developed into the Sport Centre,‚Äù McMacken points out. ‚ÄúThen we moved to Ballyguddin. We rented it for years and we eventually bought it and developed it. It was a field with fencing around. In , they dug it up and made a pitch out of it.‚Äù Terences father, John Joe, had got involved in the club after ing from Belfast where he was working and supporting Belfast Celtic. He was following the Derry and Dungiven GAA teams, before being asked to get involved in Dungiven Celtic. ‚ÄúHe played major role in the club from then on. He kept it going in bad times during the troubles, when it was tough going,‚Äù said Terence, who later wrote a poem as a tribute to his late father. ‚ÄúHe didnt get to see the pitch finished. When they came into work on the pitch, he died a week after.‚Äù Terence now looks after the pitch. Seamus Harkin hails the endless hours he puts into it. ‚ÄúYoull probably find him out there any way, just making sure it is in pristine condition.‚Äù Dermott McCloskey was another who poured his le into the club after his playing days, whether it was coaching or whatever needed done. ‚ÄúDermott was a big influence in procuring the pitch on a permanent basis and developing it,‚Äù McMacken adds. Another club stalwart remembered at the club dinner was Patsy Donaghy. Not many Dungiven Celtic players will remember him not being around the club during his letime. He famously reminded Gerard Kelly to stay on his feet. ‚ÄúGet up Kelly, you need studs on your arse,‚Äù he would say. ‚ÄúPatsy was a permanent fixture,‚Äù McMacken recalls. ‚ÄúHe never played, but he was the club linesman ‚Äì one of those guys. Every club has them...and the flag was pointing one way most of the time.‚Äù So many offered time over the years to take Dungiven Celtic from Sam McDonnells house to their new home at Ballyguddin, but by the early s the first team was really beginning to come of age. McMacken, who would rather be watching the local underage blossom than watching soccer on the telly, remembers being down at the pitch one Saturday as the they young guns began to filter into the first team. An onlooker expressed how well the team was playing. ‚ÄúIll tell you what...youve a team there for  years,‚Äù McMacken was told. And so there was. Of the  players that formed the crux of that squad about  of them wouldve been there all the way through. For most of a decade. ‚ÄúYou might have had the odd boy going away to England or America, but it was dferent times then ‚Äì boys were there to train and to play,‚Äù McMacken added. ‚ÄúWe had a lot of boys playing Gaelic and hurling, they mixed it up the best. All three codes were doing very well. ‚ÄúThe fact it was a community thing means there were days when you had to do without guys, thats the way it has to be.‚Äù It brought McMacken to the story of a weekend when Dungiven Celtic were down to play an Irish Cup tie in Belfast against Donegal Celtic, on the same Saturday Dungivens Gaelic team were set to play Bellaghy. The Belfast club accepted the request for an earlier kick-off to accommodate five players to jump into a car and head to Bellaghy. ‚ÄúWe won -, they were a really good team. It was an outstanding game and our boys were shattered after it,‚Äù said McMacken. Emmett McKeever was man of the match and was one of the players on their way to Bellaghy for part two of their super Saturday. Dungiven beat Bellaghy and later the that night, McMacken was informed that McKeever was the star of the show for the second time that day. ‚ÄúI didnt even know how he was able to walk again after the way he played. There was two games where he was man of the match in one day.‚Äù It was the   season when the breakthrough came with the clubs first intermediate League title. They lost only once, to Strabane, during their -game march to glory. They were - down in one game, away to Roe Valley, before Seamus Harkins hat-trick pulled victory from the jaws of defeat. Harkin bagged another two goals in another important clash, as Celtic saw off Dergview and they never looked back. The following season was an even better one, with all three teams ‚Äì firsts, reserves and thirds ‚Äì all winning their respective league titles. The firsts needed to avoid defeat in the final game of the season in a decider with Strabane, a game that ended scoreless, and Dungiven had retained their title. Six days later a - win over Park saw the reserves crowned champions and the thirds made it a clean sweep, but they did it the hard way. After going six games without a win, they won  of the remaining  games. The firsts added the intermediate challenge cup and the McGrogan Memorial Cup, to round off a season that brought five trophies. After the gap of a year, Dungiven came back to win their third Intermediate League title to cement it as the clubs most memorable period. Fast forward to the present day and the future looks equally rosy. In recent years, the club were honoured by the IFA as the Club of the Year. ‚ÄúDungiven Celtic Football has consistently excelled in its work for youth football in the local area,‚Äù read part of the response from the judging . ‚ÄúThe club‚Äôs community work has also been exemplary having successfully managed to build signicant participation in the local area.‚Äù After becoming an established club, the award rubber-stamps their commitment to the future ‚ÄúWe have come a long way and it can fall apart very quickly,‚Äù is the take of Terence McMacken. ‚ÄúIt is like any other club, it depends on the people. We are lucky at the moment, we have very good people involved. What we have....one, two or three people couldnt do.‚Äù He refers to the parental support and how the club is run very much on the GAA model, for the community and with everyone rowing in behind each other. McMacken refers to other clubs in Dungivens league paying their players, but he is adamant their way is the one that needs to remain. ‚ÄúTheyhave loyalty, that is the big thing. It is hard to get that in soccer. It is a dferent game, there are dferent rules and it is run dferently. ‚ÄúWe are playing teams on Saturdays where players are getting paid, where our guys are putting in a fiver to play. It is a thing we think is right.‚Äù The money goes towards the running of the club and all the admin fees that are hidden from the eye of a player every Saturday. The underage players all contribute a pound, which helps towards the booking of training facilities. Other clubs have players getting offered money here and there with goal bonuses. ‚ÄúThen there are clubs, like ourselves, who arent. I wouldnt like to see it changed. You are asking them to be part of a club, to sell tickets or whatever, the same as the six-year-olds.‚Äù The balls might be flying around Ballyguddin before the season is out, but the chances are they wont as players are kept tucked up at home for the safety of the nation in the facing the coronavirus outbreak. When the action s, the surface will be like a carpet and there will be smiles on the kids faces as they mix with their peers once again. The meeting in Sean ODonnells house was only the beginning. The club has been passed on, with interest. Its in a healthy state. Heres to the next  years. Grab Tuesdays County Derry Post for an interview with Jim McGroarty as he talks Celtic, Stoke and the secret to Dungivens success.
